title: Sonnet I
line: FROM fairest creatures we desire increase,

title: Sonnet I
line: That thereby beauty's rose might never die,

title: Sonnet I
line: But as the riper should by time decease,

title: Sonnet I
line: His tender heir might bear his memory:

title: Sonnet I
line: But thou, contracted to thine own bright eyes,

title: Sonnet I
line: Feed'st thy light'st flame with self-substantial fuel,

title: Sonnet I
line: Making a famine where abundance lies,

title: Sonnet I
line: Thyself thy foe, to thy sweet self too cruel.

title: Sonnet I
line: Thou that art now the world's fresh ornament

title: Sonnet I
line: And only herald to the gaudy spring,

title: Sonnet I
line: Within thine own bud buriest thy content

title: Sonnet I
line: And, tender churl, makest waste in niggarding.

title: Sonnet I
line: Pity the world, or else this glutton be,

title: Sonnet I
line: To eat the world's due, by the grave and thee.

title: Sonnet II
line: When forty winters shall beseige thy brow,

title: Sonnet II
line: And dig deep trenches in thy beauty's field,

title: Sonnet II
line: Thy youth's proud livery, so gazed on now,

title: Sonnet II
line: Will be a tatter'd weed, of small worth held:

title: Sonnet II
line: Then being ask'd where all thy beauty lies,

title: Sonnet II
line: Where all the treasure of thy lusty days,

title: Sonnet II
line: To say, within thine own deep-sunken eyes,

title: Sonnet II
line: Were an all-eating shame and thriftless praise.

title: Sonnet II
line: How much more praise deserved thy beauty's use,

title: Sonnet II
line: If thou couldst answer 'This fair child of mine

title: Sonnet II
line: Shall sum my count and make my old excuse,'

title: Sonnet II
line: Proving his beauty by succession thine!

title: Sonnet II
line: This were to be new made when thou art old,

title: Sonnet II
line: And see thy blood warm when thou feel'st it cold.

title: Sonnet III
line: Look in thy glass, and tell the face thou viewest

title: Sonnet III
line: Now is the time that face should form another;

title: Sonnet III
line: Whose fresh repair if now thou not renewest,

title: Sonnet III
line: Thou dost beguile the world, unbless some mother.

title: Sonnet III
line: For where is she so fair whose unear'd womb

title: Sonnet III
line: Disdains the tillage of thy husbandry?

title: Sonnet III
line: Or who is he so fond will be the tomb

title: Sonnet III
line: Of his self-love, to stop posterity?

title: Sonnet III
line: Thou art thy mother's glass, and she in thee

title: Sonnet III
line: Calls back the lovely April of her prime:

title: Sonnet III
line: So thou through windows of thine age shall see

title: Sonnet III
line: Despite of wrinkles this thy golden time.

title: Sonnet III
line: But if thou live, remember'd not to be,

title: Sonnet III
line: Die single, and thine image dies with thee.

title: Sonnet IV
line: Unthrifty loveliness, why dost thou spend

title: Sonnet IV
line: Upon thyself thy beauty's legacy?

title: Sonnet IV
line: Nature's bequest gives nothing but doth lend,

title: Sonnet IV
line: And being frank she lends to those are free.

title: Sonnet IV
line: Then, beauteous niggard, why dost thou abuse

title: Sonnet IV
line: The bounteous largess given thee to give?

title: Sonnet IV
line: Profitless usurer, why dost thou use

title: Sonnet IV
line: So great a sum of sums, yet canst not live?

title: Sonnet IV
line: For having traffic with thyself alone,

title: Sonnet IV
line: Thou of thyself thy sweet self dost deceive.

title: Sonnet IV
line: Then how, when nature calls thee to be gone,

title: Sonnet IV
line: What acceptable audit canst thou leave?

title: Sonnet IV
line: Thy unused beauty must be tomb'd with thee,

title: Sonnet IV
line: Which, used, lives th' executor to be.

title: Sonnet V
line: Those hours, that with gentle work did frame

title: Sonnet V
line: The lovely gaze where every eye doth dwell,

title: Sonnet V
line: Will play the tyrants to the very same

title: Sonnet V
line: And that unfair which fairly doth excel:

title: Sonnet V
line: For never-resting time leads summer on

title: Sonnet V
line: To hideous winter and confounds him there;

title: Sonnet V
line: Sap cheque'd with frost and lusty leaves quite gone,

title: Sonnet V
line: Beauty o'ersnow'd and bareness every where:

title: Sonnet V
line: Then, were not summer's distillation left,

title: Sonnet V
line: A liquid prisoner pent in walls of glass,

title: Sonnet V
line: Beauty's effect with beauty were bereft,

title: Sonnet V
line: Nor it nor no remembrance what it was:

title: Sonnet V
line: But flowers distill'd though they with winter meet,

title: Sonnet V
line: Leese but their show; their substance still lives sweet.

title: Sonnet VI
line: Then let not winter's ragged hand deface

title: Sonnet VI
line: In thee thy summer, ere thou be distill'd:

title: Sonnet VI
line: Make sweet some vial; treasure thou some place

title: Sonnet VI
line: With beauty's treasure, ere it be self-kill'd.

title: Sonnet VI
line: That use is not forbidden usury,

title: Sonnet VI
line: Which happies those that pay the willing loan;

title: Sonnet VI
line: That's for thyself to breed another thee,

title: Sonnet VI
line: Or ten times happier, be it ten for one;

title: Sonnet VI
line: Ten times thyself were happier than thou art,

title: Sonnet VI
line: If ten of thine ten times refigured thee:

title: Sonnet VI
line: Then what could death do, if thou shouldst depart,

title: Sonnet VI
line: Leaving thee living in posterity?

title: Sonnet VI
line: Be not self-will'd, for thou art much too fair

title: Sonnet VI
line: To be death's conquest and make worms thine heir.

title: Sonnet VII
line: Lo! in the orient when the gracious light

title: Sonnet VII
line: Lifts up his burning head, each under eye

title: Sonnet VII
line: Doth homage to his new-appearing sight,

title: Sonnet VII
line: Serving with looks his sacred majesty;

title: Sonnet VII
line: And having climb'd the steep-up heavenly hill,

title: Sonnet VII
line: Resembling strong youth in his middle age,

title: Sonnet VII
line: yet mortal looks adore his beauty still,

title: Sonnet VII
line: Attending on his golden pilgrimage;

title: Sonnet VII
line: But when from highmost pitch, with weary car,

title: Sonnet VII
line: Like feeble age, he reeleth from the day,

title: Sonnet VII
line: The eyes, 'fore duteous, now converted are

title: Sonnet VII
line: From his low tract and look another way:

title: Sonnet VII
line: So thou, thyself out-going in thy noon,

title: Sonnet VII
line: Unlook'd on diest, unless thou get a son.

title: Sonnet VIII
line: Music to hear, why hear'st thou music sadly?

title: Sonnet VIII
line: Sweets with sweets war not, joy delights in joy.

title: Sonnet VIII
line: Why lovest thou that which thou receivest not gladly,

title: Sonnet VIII
line: Or else receivest with pleasure thine annoy?

title: Sonnet VIII
line: If the true concord of well-tuned sounds,

title: Sonnet VIII
line: By unions married, do offend thine ear,

title: Sonnet VIII
line: They do but sweetly chide thee, who confounds

title: Sonnet VIII
line: In singleness the parts that thou shouldst bear.

title: Sonnet VIII
line: Mark how one string, sweet husband to another,

title: Sonnet VIII
line: Strikes each in each by mutual ordering,

title: Sonnet VIII
line: Resembling sire and child and happy mother

title: Sonnet VIII
line: Who all in one, one pleasing note do sing:

title: Sonnet VIII
line: Whose speechless song, being many, seeming one,

title: Sonnet VIII
line: Sings this to thee: 'thou single wilt prove none.'

title: Sonnet IX
line: Is it for fear to wet a widow's eye

title: Sonnet IX
line: That thou consumest thyself in single life?

title: Sonnet IX
line: Ah! if thou issueless shalt hap to die.

title: Sonnet IX
line: The world will wail thee, like a makeless wife;

title: Sonnet IX
line: The world will be thy widow and still weep

title: Sonnet IX
line: That thou no form of thee hast left behind,

title: Sonnet IX
line: When every private widow well may keep

title: Sonnet IX
line: By children's eyes her husband's shape in mind.

title: Sonnet IX
line: Look, what an unthrift in the world doth spend

title: Sonnet IX
line: Shifts but his place, for still the world enjoys it;

title: Sonnet IX
line: But beauty's waste hath in the world an end,

title: Sonnet IX
line: And kept unused, the user so destroys it.

title: Sonnet IX
line: No love toward others in that bosom sits

title: Sonnet IX
line: That on himself such murderous shame commits.

title: Sonnet X
line: For shame! deny that thou bear'st love to any,

title: Sonnet X
line: Who for thyself art so unprovident.

title: Sonnet X
line: Grant, if thou wilt, thou art beloved of many,

title: Sonnet X
line: But that thou none lovest is most evident;

title: Sonnet X
line: For thou art so possess'd with murderous hate

title: Sonnet X
line: That 'gainst thyself thou stick'st not to conspire.

title: Sonnet X
line: Seeking that beauteous roof to ruinate

title: Sonnet X
line: Which to repair should be thy chief desire.

title: Sonnet X
line: O, change thy thought, that I may change my mind!

title: Sonnet X
line: Shall hate be fairer lodged than gentle love?

title: Sonnet X
line: Be, as thy presence is, gracious and kind,

title: Sonnet X
line: Or to thyself at least kind-hearted prove:

title: Sonnet X
line: Make thee another self, for love of me,

title: Sonnet X
line: That beauty still may live in thine or thee.

title: Sonnet XI
line: As fast as thou shalt wane, so fast thou growest

title: Sonnet XI
line: In one of thine, from that which thou departest;

title: Sonnet XI
line: And that fresh blood which youngly thou bestowest

title: Sonnet XI
line: Thou mayst call thine when thou from youth convertest.

title: Sonnet XI
line: Herein lives wisdom, beauty and increase:

title: Sonnet XI
line: Without this, folly, age and cold decay:

title: Sonnet XI
line: If all were minded so, the times should cease

title: Sonnet XI
line: And threescore year would make the world away.

title: Sonnet XI
line: Let those whom Nature hath not made for store,

title: Sonnet XI
line: Harsh featureless and rude, barrenly perish:

title: Sonnet XI
line: Look, whom she best endow'd she gave the more;

title: Sonnet XI
line: Which bounteous gift thou shouldst in bounty cherish:

title: Sonnet XI
line: She carved thee for her seal, and meant thereby

title: Sonnet XI
line: Thou shouldst print more, not let that copy die.

title: Sonnet XII
line: When I do count the clock that tells the time,

title: Sonnet XII
line: And see the brave day sunk in hideous night;

title: Sonnet XII
line: When I behold the violet past prime,

title: Sonnet XII
line: And sable curls all silver'd o'er with white;

title: Sonnet XII
line: When lofty trees I see barren of leaves

title: Sonnet XII
line: Which erst from heat did canopy the herd,

title: Sonnet XII
line: And summer's green all girded up in sheaves

title: Sonnet XII
line: Borne on the bier with white and bristly beard,

title: Sonnet XII
line: Then of thy beauty do I question make,

title: Sonnet XII
line: That thou among the wastes of time must go,

title: Sonnet XII
line: Since sweets and beauties do themselves forsake

title: Sonnet XII
line: And die as fast as they see others grow;

title: Sonnet XII
line: And nothing 'gainst Time's scythe can make defence

title: Sonnet XII
line: Save breed, to brave him when he takes thee hence.

title: Sonnet XIII
line: O, that you were yourself! but, love, you are

title: Sonnet XIII
line: No longer yours than you yourself here live:

title: Sonnet XIII
line: Against this coming end you should prepare,

title: Sonnet XIII
line: And your sweet semblance to some other give.

title: Sonnet XIII
line: So should that beauty which you hold in lease

title: Sonnet XIII
line: Find no determination: then you were

title: Sonnet XIII
line: Yourself again after yourself's decease,

title: Sonnet XIII
line: When your sweet issue your sweet form should bear.

title: Sonnet XIII
line: Who lets so fair a house fall to decay,

title: Sonnet XIII
line: Which husbandry in honour might uphold

title: Sonnet XIII
line: Against the stormy gusts of winter's day

title: Sonnet XIII
line: And barren rage of death's eternal cold?

title: Sonnet XIII
line: O, none but unthrifts! Dear my love, you know

title: Sonnet XIII
line: You had a father: let your son say so.

title: Sonnet XIV
line: Not from the stars do I my judgment pluck;

title: Sonnet XIV
line: And yet methinks I have astronomy,

title: Sonnet XIV
line: But not to tell of good or evil luck,

title: Sonnet XIV
line: Of plagues, of dearths, or seasons' quality;

title: Sonnet XIV
line: Nor can I fortune to brief minutes tell,

title: Sonnet XIV
line: Pointing to each his thunder, rain and wind,

title: Sonnet XIV
line: Or say with princes if it shall go well,

title: Sonnet XIV
line: By oft predict that I in heaven find:

title: Sonnet XIV
line: But from thine eyes my knowledge I derive,

title: Sonnet XIV
line: And, constant stars, in them I read such art

title: Sonnet XIV
line: As truth and beauty shall together thrive,

title: Sonnet XIV
line: If from thyself to store thou wouldst convert;

title: Sonnet XIV
line: Or else of thee this I prognosticate:

title: Sonnet XIV
line: Thy end is truth's and beauty's doom and date.

title: Sonnet XV
line: When I consider every thing that grows

title: Sonnet XV
line: Holds in perfection but a little moment,

title: Sonnet XV
line: That this huge stage presenteth nought but shows

title: Sonnet XV
line: Whereon the stars in secret influence comment;

title: Sonnet XV
line: When I perceive that men as plants increase,

title: Sonnet XV
line: Cheered and cheque'd even by the self-same sky,

title: Sonnet XV
line: Vaunt in their youthful sap, at height decrease,

title: Sonnet XV
line: And wear their brave state out of memory;

title: Sonnet XV
line: Then the conceit of this inconstant stay

title: Sonnet XV
line: Sets you most rich in youth before my sight,

title: Sonnet XV
line: Where wasteful Time debateth with Decay,

title: Sonnet XV
line: To change your day of youth to sullied night;

title: Sonnet XV
line: And all in war with Time for love of you,

title: Sonnet XV
line: As he takes from you, I engraft you new.

title: Sonnet XVI
line: But wherefore do not you a mightier way

title: Sonnet XVI
line: Make war upon this bloody tyrant, Time?

title: Sonnet XVI
line: And fortify yourself in your decay

title: Sonnet XVI
line: With means more blessed than my barren rhyme?

title: Sonnet XVI
line: Now stand you on the top of happy hours,

title: Sonnet XVI
line: And many maiden gardens yet unset

title: Sonnet XVI
line: With virtuous wish would bear your living flowers,

title: Sonnet XVI
line: Much liker than your painted counterfeit:

title: Sonnet XVI
line: So should the lines of life that life repair,

title: Sonnet XVI
line: Which this, Time's pencil, or my pupil pen,

title: Sonnet XVI
line: Neither in inward worth nor outward fair,

title: Sonnet XVI
line: Can make you live yourself in eyes of men.

title: Sonnet XVI
line: To give away yourself keeps yourself still,

title: Sonnet XVI
line: And you must live, drawn by your own sweet skill.

title: Sonnet XVII
line: Who will believe my verse in time to come,

title: Sonnet XVII
line: If it were fill'd with your most high deserts?

title: Sonnet XVII
line: Though yet, heaven knows, it is but as a tomb

title: Sonnet XVII
line: Which hides your life and shows not half your parts.

title: Sonnet XVII
line: If I could write the beauty of your eyes

title: Sonnet XVII
line: And in fresh numbers number all your graces,

title: Sonnet XVII
line: The age to come would say 'This poet lies:

title: Sonnet XVII
line: Such heavenly touches ne'er touch'd earthly faces.'

title: Sonnet XVII
line: So should my papers yellow'd with their age

title: Sonnet XVII
line: Be scorn'd like old men of less truth than tongue,

title: Sonnet XVII
line: And your true rights be term'd a poet's rage

title: Sonnet XVII
line: And stretched metre of an antique song:

title: Sonnet XVII
line: But were some child of yours alive that time,

title: Sonnet XVII
line: You should live twice; in it and in my rhyme.

title: Sonnet XVIII
line: Shall I compare thee to a summer's day?

title: Sonnet XVIII
line: Thou art more lovely and more temperate:

title: Sonnet XVIII
line: Rough winds do shake the darling buds of May,

title: Sonnet XVIII
line: And summer's lease hath all too short a date:

title: Sonnet XVIII
line: Sometime too hot the eye of heaven shines,

title: Sonnet XVIII
line: And often is his gold complexion dimm'd;

title: Sonnet XVIII
line: And every fair from fair sometime declines,

title: Sonnet XVIII
line: By chance or nature's changing course untrimm'd;

title: Sonnet XVIII
line: But thy eternal summer shall not fade

title: Sonnet XVIII
line: Nor lose possession of that fair thou owest;

title: Sonnet XVIII
line: Nor shall Death brag thou wander'st in his shade,

title: Sonnet XVIII
line: When in eternal lines to time thou growest:

title: Sonnet XVIII
line: So long as men can breathe or eyes can see,

title: Sonnet XVIII
line: So long lives this and this gives life to thee.

title: Sonnet XIX
line: Devouring Time, blunt thou the lion's paws,

title: Sonnet XIX
line: And make the earth devour her own sweet brood;

title: Sonnet XIX
line: Pluck the keen teeth from the fierce tiger's jaws,

title: Sonnet XIX
line: And burn the long-lived phoenix in her blood;

title: Sonnet XIX
line: Make glad and sorry seasons as thou fleets,

title: Sonnet XIX
line: And do whate'er thou wilt, swift-footed Time,

title: Sonnet XIX
line: To the wide world and all her fading sweets;

title: Sonnet XIX
line: But I forbid thee one most heinous crime:

title: Sonnet XIX
line: O, carve not with thy hours my love's fair brow,

title: Sonnet XIX
line: Nor draw no lines there with thine antique pen;

title: Sonnet XIX
line: Him in thy course untainted do allow

title: Sonnet XIX
line: For beauty's pattern to succeeding men.

title: Sonnet XIX
line: Yet, do thy worst, old Time: despite thy wrong,

title: Sonnet XIX
line: My love shall in my verse ever live young.

title: Sonnet XX
line: A woman's face with Nature's own hand painted

title: Sonnet XX
line: Hast thou, the master-mistress of my passion;

title: Sonnet XX
line: A woman's gentle heart, but not acquainted

title: Sonnet XX
line: With shifting change, as is false women's fashion;

title: Sonnet XX
line: An eye more bright than theirs, less false in rolling,

title: Sonnet XX
line: Gilding the object whereupon it gazeth;

title: Sonnet XX
line: A man in hue, all 'hues' in his controlling,

title: Sonnet XX
line: Much steals men's eyes and women's souls amazeth.

title: Sonnet XX
line: And for a woman wert thou first created;

title: Sonnet XX
line: Till Nature, as she wrought thee, fell a-doting,

title: Sonnet XX
line: And by addition me of thee defeated,

title: Sonnet XX
line: By adding one thing to my purpose nothing.

title: Sonnet XX
line: But since she prick'd thee out for women's pleasure,

title: Sonnet XX
line: Mine be thy love and thy love's use their treasure.

title: Sonnet XXI
line: So is it not with me as with that Muse

title: Sonnet XXI
line: Stirr'd by a painted beauty to his verse,

title: Sonnet XXI
line: Who heaven itself for ornament doth use

title: Sonnet XXI
line: And every fair with his fair doth rehearse

title: Sonnet XXI
line: Making a couplement of proud compare,

title: Sonnet XXI
line: With sun and moon, with earth and sea's rich gems,

title: Sonnet XXI
line: With April's first-born flowers, and all things rare

title: Sonnet XXI
line: That heaven's air in this huge rondure hems.

title: Sonnet XXI
line: O' let me, true in love, but truly write,

title: Sonnet XXI
line: And then believe me, my love is as fair

title: Sonnet XXI
line: As any mother's child, though not so bright

title: Sonnet XXI
line: As those gold candles fix'd in heaven's air:

title: Sonnet XXI
line: Let them say more than like of hearsay well;

title: Sonnet XXI
line: I will not praise that purpose not to sell.

title: Sonnet XXII
line: My glass shall not persuade me I am old,

title: Sonnet XXII
line: So long as youth and thou are of one date;

title: Sonnet XXII
line: But when in thee time's furrows I behold,

title: Sonnet XXII
line: Then look I death my days should expiate.

title: Sonnet XXII
line: For all that beauty that doth cover thee

title: Sonnet XXII
line: Is but the seemly raiment of my heart,

title: Sonnet XXII
line: Which in thy breast doth live, as thine in me:

title: Sonnet XXII
line: How can I then be elder than thou art?

title: Sonnet XXII
line: O, therefore, love, be of thyself so wary

title: Sonnet XXII
line: As I, not for myself, but for thee will;

title: Sonnet XXII
line: Bearing thy heart, which I will keep so chary

title: Sonnet XXII
line: As tender nurse her babe from faring ill.

title: Sonnet XXII
line: Presume not on thy heart when mine is slain;

title: Sonnet XXII
line: Thou gavest me thine, not to give back again.

title: Sonnet XXIII
line: As an unperfect actor on the stage

title: Sonnet XXIII
line: Who with his fear is put besides his part,

title: Sonnet XXIII
line: Or some fierce thing replete with too much rage,

title: Sonnet XXIII
line: Whose strength's abundance weakens his own heart.

title: Sonnet XXIII
line: So I, for fear of trust, forget to say

title: Sonnet XXIII
line: The perfect ceremony of love's rite,

title: Sonnet XXIII
line: And in mine own love's strength seem to decay,

title: Sonnet XXIII
line: O'ercharged with burden of mine own love's might.

title: Sonnet XXIII
line: O, let my books be then the eloquence

title: Sonnet XXIII
line: And dumb presagers of my speaking breast,

title: Sonnet XXIII
line: Who plead for love and look for recompense

title: Sonnet XXIII
line: More than that tongue that more hath more express'd.

title: Sonnet XXIII
line: O, learn to read what silent love hath writ:

title: Sonnet XXIII
line: To hear with eyes belongs to love's fine wit.

title: Sonnet XXIV
line: Mine eye hath play'd the painter and hath stell'd

title: Sonnet XXIV
line: Thy beauty's form in table of my heart;

title: Sonnet XXIV
line: My body is the frame wherein 'tis held,

title: Sonnet XXIV
line: And perspective it is the painter's art.

title: Sonnet XXIV
line: For through the painter must you see his skill,

title: Sonnet XXIV
line: To find where your true image pictured lies;

title: Sonnet XXIV
line: Which in my bosom's shop is hanging still,

title: Sonnet XXIV
line: That hath his windows glazed with thine eyes.

title: Sonnet XXIV
line: Now see what good turns eyes for eyes have done:

title: Sonnet XXIV
line: Mine eyes have drawn thy shape, and thine for me

title: Sonnet XXIV
line: Are windows to my breast, where-through the sun

title: Sonnet XXIV
line: Delights to peep, to gaze therein on thee;

title: Sonnet XXIV
line: Yet eyes this cunning want to grace their art;

title: Sonnet XXIV
line: They draw but what they see, know not the heart.

title: Sonnet XXV
line: Let those who are in favour with their stars

title: Sonnet XXV
line: Of public honour and proud titles boast,

title: Sonnet XXV
line: Whilst I, whom fortune of such triumph bars,

title: Sonnet XXV
line: Unlook'd for joy in that I honour most.

title: Sonnet XXV
line: Great princes' favourites their fair leaves spread

title: Sonnet XXV
line: But as the marigold at the sun's eye,

title: Sonnet XXV
line: And in themselves their pride lies buried,

title: Sonnet XXV
line: For at a frown they in their glory die.

title: Sonnet XXV
line: The painful warrior famoused for fight,

title: Sonnet XXV
line: After a thousand victories once foil'd,

title: Sonnet XXV
line: Is from the book of honour razed quite,

title: Sonnet XXV
line: And all the rest forgot for which he toil'd:

title: Sonnet XXV
line: Then happy I, that love and am beloved

title: Sonnet XXV
line: Where I may not remove nor be removed.

title: Sonnet XXVI
line: Lord of my love, to whom in vassalage

title: Sonnet XXVI
line: Thy merit hath my duty strongly knit,

title: Sonnet XXVI
line: To thee I send this written embassage,

title: Sonnet XXVI
line: To witness duty, not to show my wit:

title: Sonnet XXVI
line: Duty so great, which wit so poor as mine

title: Sonnet XXVI
line: May make seem bare, in wanting words to show it,

title: Sonnet XXVI
line: But that I hope some good conceit of thine

title: Sonnet XXVI
line: In thy soul's thought, all naked, will bestow it;

title: Sonnet XXVI
line: Till whatsoever star that guides my moving

title: Sonnet XXVI
line: Points on me graciously with fair aspect

title: Sonnet XXVI
line: And puts apparel on my tatter'd loving,

title: Sonnet XXVI
line: To show me worthy of thy sweet respect:

title: Sonnet XXVI
line: Then may I dare to boast how I do love thee;

title: Sonnet XXVI
line: Till then not show my head where thou mayst prove me.

title: Sonnet XXVII
line: Weary with toil, I haste me to my bed,

title: Sonnet XXVII
line: The dear repose for limbs with travel tired;

title: Sonnet XXVII
line: But then begins a journey in my head,

title: Sonnet XXVII
line: To work my mind, when body's work's expired:

title: Sonnet XXVII
line: For then my thoughts, from far where I abide,

title: Sonnet XXVII
line: Intend a zealous pilgrimage to thee,

title: Sonnet XXVII
line: And keep my drooping eyelids open wide,

title: Sonnet XXVII
line: Looking on darkness which the blind do see

title: Sonnet XXVII
line: Save that my soul's imaginary sight

title: Sonnet XXVII
line: Presents thy shadow to my sightless view,

title: Sonnet XXVII
line: Which, like a jewel hung in ghastly night,

title: Sonnet XXVII
line: Makes black night beauteous and her old face new.

title: Sonnet XXVII
line: Lo! thus, by day my limbs, by night my mind,

title: Sonnet XXVII
line: For thee and for myself no quiet find.

title: Sonnet XXVIII
line: How can I then return in happy plight,

title: Sonnet XXVIII
line: That am debarr'd the benefit of rest?

title: Sonnet XXVIII
line: When day's oppression is not eased by night,

title: Sonnet XXVIII
line: But day by night, and night by day, oppress'd?

title: Sonnet XXVIII
line: And each, though enemies to either's reign,

title: Sonnet XXVIII
line: Do in consent shake hands to torture me;

title: Sonnet XXVIII
line: The one by toil, the other to complain

title: Sonnet XXVIII
line: How far I toil, still farther off from thee.

title: Sonnet XXVIII
line: I tell the day, to please them thou art bright

title: Sonnet XXVIII
line: And dost him grace when clouds do blot the heaven:

title: Sonnet XXVIII
line: So flatter I the swart-complexion'd night,

title: Sonnet XXVIII
line: When sparkling stars twire not thou gild'st the even.

title: Sonnet XXVIII
line: But day doth daily draw my sorrows longer

title: Sonnet XXVIII
line: And night doth nightly make grief's strength

title: Sonnet XXVIII
line: seem stronger.

title: Sonnet XXIX
line: When, in disgrace with fortune and men's eyes,

title: Sonnet XXIX
line: I all alone beweep my outcast state

title: Sonnet XXIX
line: And trouble deaf heaven with my bootless cries

title: Sonnet XXIX
line: And look upon myself and curse my fate,

title: Sonnet XXIX
line: Wishing me like to one more rich in hope,

title: Sonnet XXIX
line: Featured like him, like him with friends possess'd,

title: Sonnet XXIX
line: Desiring this man's art and that man's scope,

title: Sonnet XXIX
line: With what I most enjoy contented least;

title: Sonnet XXIX
line: Yet in these thoughts myself almost despising,

title: Sonnet XXIX
line: Haply I think on thee, and then my state,

title: Sonnet XXIX
line: Like to the lark at break of day arising

title: Sonnet XXIX
line: From sullen earth, sings hymns at heaven's gate;

title: Sonnet XXIX
line: For thy sweet love remember'd such wealth brings

title: Sonnet XXIX
line: That then I scorn to change my state with kings.

title: Sonnet XXX
line: When to the sessions of sweet silent thought

title: Sonnet XXX
line: I summon up remembrance of things past,

title: Sonnet XXX
line: I sigh the lack of many a thing I sought,

title: Sonnet XXX
line: And with old woes new wail my dear time's waste:

title: Sonnet XXX
line: Then can I drown an eye, unused to flow,

title: Sonnet XXX
line: For precious friends hid in death's dateless night,

title: Sonnet XXX
line: And weep afresh love's long since cancell'd woe,

title: Sonnet XXX
line: And moan the expense of many a vanish'd sight:

title: Sonnet XXX
line: Then can I grieve at grievances foregone,

title: Sonnet XXX
line: And heavily from woe to woe tell o'er

title: Sonnet XXX
line: The sad account of fore-bemoaned moan,

title: Sonnet XXX
line: Which I new pay as if not paid before.

title: Sonnet XXX
line: But if the while I think on thee, dear friend,

title: Sonnet XXX
line: All losses are restored and sorrows end.

title: Sonnet XXXI
line: Thy bosom is endeared with all hearts,

title: Sonnet XXXI
line: Which I by lacking have supposed dead,

title: Sonnet XXXI
line: And there reigns love and all love's loving parts,

title: Sonnet XXXI
line: And all those friends which I thought buried.

title: Sonnet XXXI
line: How many a holy and obsequious tear

title: Sonnet XXXI
line: Hath dear religious love stol'n from mine eye

title: Sonnet XXXI
line: As interest of the dead, which now appear

title: Sonnet XXXI
line: But things removed that hidden in thee lie!

title: Sonnet XXXI
line: Thou art the grave where buried love doth live,

title: Sonnet XXXI
line: Hung with the trophies of my lovers gone,

title: Sonnet XXXI
line: Who all their parts of me to thee did give;

title: Sonnet XXXI
line: That due of many now is thine alone:

title: Sonnet XXXI
line: Their images I loved I view in thee,

title: Sonnet XXXI
line: And thou, all they, hast all the all of me.

title: Sonnet XXXII
line: If thou survive my well-contented day,

title: Sonnet XXXII
line: When that churl Death my bones with dust shall cover,

title: Sonnet XXXII
line: And shalt by fortune once more re-survey

title: Sonnet XXXII
line: These poor rude lines of thy deceased lover,

title: Sonnet XXXII
line: Compare them with the bettering of the time,

title: Sonnet XXXII
line: And though they be outstripp'd by every pen,

title: Sonnet XXXII
line: Reserve them for my love, not for their rhyme,

title: Sonnet XXXII
line: Exceeded by the height of happier men.

title: Sonnet XXXII
line: O, then vouchsafe me but this loving thought:

title: Sonnet XXXII
line: 'Had my friend's Muse grown with this growing age,

title: Sonnet XXXII
line: A dearer birth than this his love had brought,

title: Sonnet XXXII
line: To march in ranks of better equipage:

title: Sonnet XXXII
line: But since he died and poets better prove,

title: Sonnet XXXII
line: Theirs for their style I'll read, his for his love.'

title: Sonnet XXXIII
line: Full many a glorious morning have I seen

title: Sonnet XXXIII
line: Flatter the mountain-tops with sovereign eye,

title: Sonnet XXXIII
line: Kissing with golden face the meadows green,

title: Sonnet XXXIII
line: Gilding pale streams with heavenly alchemy;

title: Sonnet XXXIII
line: Anon permit the basest clouds to ride

title: Sonnet XXXIII
line: With ugly rack on his celestial face,

title: Sonnet XXXIII
line: And from the forlorn world his visage hide,

title: Sonnet XXXIII
line: Stealing unseen to west with this disgrace:

title: Sonnet XXXIII
line: Even so my sun one early morn did shine

title: Sonnet XXXIII
line: With all triumphant splendor on my brow;

title: Sonnet XXXIII
line: But out, alack! he was but one hour mine;

title: Sonnet XXXIII
line: The region cloud hath mask'd him from me now.

title: Sonnet XXXIII
line: Yet him for this my love no whit disdaineth;

title: Sonnet XXXIII
line: Suns of the world may stain when heaven's sun staineth.

title: Sonnet XXXIV
line: Why didst thou promise such a beauteous day,

title: Sonnet XXXIV
line: And make me travel forth without my cloak,

title: Sonnet XXXIV
line: To let base clouds o'ertake me in my way,

title: Sonnet XXXIV
line: Hiding thy bravery in their rotten smoke?

title: Sonnet XXXIV
line: 'Tis not enough that through the cloud thou break,

title: Sonnet XXXIV
line: To dry the rain on my storm-beaten face,

title: Sonnet XXXIV
line: For no man well of such a salve can speak

title: Sonnet XXXIV
line: That heals the wound and cures not the disgrace:

title: Sonnet XXXIV
line: Nor can thy shame give physic to my grief;

title: Sonnet XXXIV
line: Though thou repent, yet I have still the loss:

title: Sonnet XXXIV
line: The offender's sorrow lends but weak relief

title: Sonnet XXXIV
line: To him that bears the strong offence's cross.

title: Sonnet XXXIV
line: Ah! but those tears are pearl which thy love sheds,

title: Sonnet XXXIV
line: And they are rich and ransom all ill deeds.

title: Sonnet XXXV
line: No more be grieved at that which thou hast done:

title: Sonnet XXXV
line: Roses have thorns, and silver fountains mud;

title: Sonnet XXXV
line: Clouds and eclipses stain both moon and sun,

title: Sonnet XXXV
line: And loathsome canker lives in sweetest bud.

title: Sonnet XXXV
line: All men make faults, and even I in this,

title: Sonnet XXXV
line: Authorizing thy trespass with compare,

title: Sonnet XXXV
line: Myself corrupting, salving thy amiss,

title: Sonnet XXXV
line: Excusing thy sins more than thy sins are;

title: Sonnet XXXV
line: For to thy sensual fault I bring in sense--

title: Sonnet XXXV
line: Thy adverse party is thy advocate--

title: Sonnet XXXV
line: And 'gainst myself a lawful plea commence:

title: Sonnet XXXV
line: Such civil war is in my love and hate

title: Sonnet XXXV
line: That I an accessary needs must be

title: Sonnet XXXV
line: To that sweet thief which sourly robs from me.

title: Sonnet XXXVI
line: Let me confess that we two must be twain,

title: Sonnet XXXVI
line: Although our undivided loves are one:

title: Sonnet XXXVI
line: So shall those blots that do with me remain

title: Sonnet XXXVI
line: Without thy help by me be borne alone.

title: Sonnet XXXVI
line: In our two loves there is but one respect,

title: Sonnet XXXVI
line: Though in our lives a separable spite,

title: Sonnet XXXVI
line: Which though it alter not love's sole effect,

title: Sonnet XXXVI
line: Yet doth it steal sweet hours from love's delight.

title: Sonnet XXXVI
line: I may not evermore acknowledge thee,

title: Sonnet XXXVI
line: Lest my bewailed guilt should do thee shame,

title: Sonnet XXXVI
line: Nor thou with public kindness honour me,

title: Sonnet XXXVI
line: Unless thou take that honour from thy name:

title: Sonnet XXXVI
line: But do not so; I love thee in such sort

title: Sonnet XXXVI
line: As, thou being mine, mine is thy good report.

title: Sonnet XXXVII
line: As a decrepit father takes delight

title: Sonnet XXXVII
line: To see his active child do deeds of youth,

title: Sonnet XXXVII
line: So I, made lame by fortune's dearest spite,

title: Sonnet XXXVII
line: Take all my comfort of thy worth and truth.

title: Sonnet XXXVII
line: For whether beauty, birth, or wealth, or wit,

title: Sonnet XXXVII
line: Or any of these all, or all, or more,

title: Sonnet XXXVII
line: Entitled in thy parts do crowned sit,

title: Sonnet XXXVII
line: I make my love engrafted to this store:

title: Sonnet XXXVII
line: So then I am not lame, poor, nor despised,

title: Sonnet XXXVII
line: Whilst that this shadow doth such substance give

title: Sonnet XXXVII
line: That I in thy abundance am sufficed

title: Sonnet XXXVII
line: And by a part of all thy glory live.

title: Sonnet XXXVII
line: Look, what is best, that best I wish in thee:

title: Sonnet XXXVII
line: This wish I have; then ten times happy me!

title: Sonnet XXXVIII
line: How can my Muse want subject to invent,

title: Sonnet XXXVIII
line: While thou dost breathe, that pour'st into my verse

title: Sonnet XXXVIII
line: Thine own sweet argument, too excellent

title: Sonnet XXXVIII
line: For every vulgar paper to rehearse?

title: Sonnet XXXVIII
line: O, give thyself the thanks, if aught in me

title: Sonnet XXXVIII
line: Worthy perusal stand against thy sight;

title: Sonnet XXXVIII
line: For who's so dumb that cannot write to thee,

title: Sonnet XXXVIII
line: When thou thyself dost give invention light?

title: Sonnet XXXVIII
line: Be thou the tenth Muse, ten times more in worth

title: Sonnet XXXVIII
line: Than those old nine which rhymers invocate;

title: Sonnet XXXVIII
line: And he that calls on thee, let him bring forth

title: Sonnet XXXVIII
line: Eternal numbers to outlive long date.

title: Sonnet XXXVIII
line: If my slight Muse do please these curious days,

title: Sonnet XXXVIII
line: The pain be mine, but thine shall be the praise.

title: Sonnet XXXIX
line: O, how thy worth with manners may I sing,

title: Sonnet XXXIX
line: When thou art all the better part of me?

title: Sonnet XXXIX
line: What can mine own praise to mine own self bring?

title: Sonnet XXXIX
line: And what is 't but mine own when I praise thee?

title: Sonnet XXXIX
line: Even for this let us divided live,

title: Sonnet XXXIX
line: And our dear love lose name of single one,

title: Sonnet XXXIX
line: That by this separation I may give

title: Sonnet XXXIX
line: That due to thee which thou deservest alone.

title: Sonnet XXXIX
line: O absence, what a torment wouldst thou prove,

title: Sonnet XXXIX
line: Were it not thy sour leisure gave sweet leave

title: Sonnet XXXIX
line: To entertain the time with thoughts of love,

title: Sonnet XXXIX
line: Which time and thoughts so sweetly doth deceive,

title: Sonnet XXXIX
line: And that thou teachest how to make one twain,

title: Sonnet XXXIX
line: By praising him here who doth hence remain!

title: Sonnet XL
line: Take all my loves, my love, yea, take them all;

title: Sonnet XL
line: What hast thou then more than thou hadst before?

title: Sonnet XL
line: No love, my love, that thou mayst true love call;

title: Sonnet XL
line: All mine was thine before thou hadst this more.

title: Sonnet XL
line: Then if for my love thou my love receivest,

title: Sonnet XL
line: I cannot blame thee for my love thou usest;

title: Sonnet XL
line: But yet be blamed, if thou thyself deceivest

title: Sonnet XL
line: By wilful taste of what thyself refusest.

title: Sonnet XL
line: I do forgive thy robbery, gentle thief,

title: Sonnet XL
line: Although thou steal thee all my poverty;

title: Sonnet XL
line: And yet, love knows, it is a greater grief

title: Sonnet XL
line: To bear love's wrong than hate's known injury.

title: Sonnet XL
line: Lascivious grace, in whom all ill well shows,

title: Sonnet XL
line: Kill me with spites; yet we must not be foes.

title: Sonnet XLI
line: Those petty wrongs that liberty commits,

title: Sonnet XLI
line: When I am sometime absent from thy heart,

title: Sonnet XLI
line: Thy beauty and thy years full well befits,

title: Sonnet XLI
line: For still temptation follows where thou art.

title: Sonnet XLI
line: Gentle thou art and therefore to be won,

title: Sonnet XLI
line: Beauteous thou art, therefore to be assailed;

title: Sonnet XLI
line: And when a woman woos, what woman's son

title: Sonnet XLI
line: Will sourly leave her till she have prevailed?

title: Sonnet XLI
line: Ay me! but yet thou mightest my seat forbear,

title: Sonnet XLI
line: And chide try beauty and thy straying youth,

title: Sonnet XLI
line: Who lead thee in their riot even there

title: Sonnet XLI
line: Where thou art forced to break a twofold truth,

title: Sonnet XLI
line: Hers by thy beauty tempting her to thee,

title: Sonnet XLI
line: Thine, by thy beauty being false to me.

title: Sonnet XLII
line: That thou hast her, it is not all my grief,

title: Sonnet XLII
line: And yet it may be said I loved her dearly;

title: Sonnet XLII
line: That she hath thee, is of my wailing chief,

title: Sonnet XLII
line: A loss in love that touches me more nearly.

title: Sonnet XLII
line: Loving offenders, thus I will excuse ye:

title: Sonnet XLII
line: Thou dost love her, because thou knowst I love her;

title: Sonnet XLII
line: And for my sake even so doth she abuse me,

title: Sonnet XLII
line: Suffering my friend for my sake to approve her.

title: Sonnet XLII
line: If I lose thee, my loss is my love's gain,

title: Sonnet XLII
line: And losing her, my friend hath found that loss;

title: Sonnet XLII
line: Both find each other, and I lose both twain,

title: Sonnet XLII
line: And both for my sake lay on me this cross:

title: Sonnet XLII
line: But here's the joy; my friend and I are one;

title: Sonnet XLII
line: Sweet flattery! then she loves but me alone.

title: Sonnet XLIII
line: When most I wink, then do mine eyes best see,

title: Sonnet XLIII
line: For all the day they view things unrespected;

title: Sonnet XLIII
line: But when I sleep, in dreams they look on thee,

title: Sonnet XLIII
line: And darkly bright are bright in dark directed.

title: Sonnet XLIII
line: Then thou, whose shadow shadows doth make bright,

title: Sonnet XLIII
line: How would thy shadow's form form happy show

title: Sonnet XLIII
line: To the clear day with thy much clearer light,

title: Sonnet XLIII
line: When to unseeing eyes thy shade shines so!

title: Sonnet XLIII
line: How would, I say, mine eyes be blessed made

title: Sonnet XLIII
line: By looking on thee in the living day,

title: Sonnet XLIII
line: When in dead night thy fair imperfect shade

title: Sonnet XLIII
line: Through heavy sleep on sightless eyes doth stay!

title: Sonnet XLIII
line: All days are nights to see till I see thee,

title: Sonnet XLIII
line: And nights bright days when dreams do show thee me.

title: Sonnet XLIV
line: If the dull substance of my flesh were thought,

title: Sonnet XLIV
line: Injurious distance should not stop my way;

title: Sonnet XLIV
line: For then despite of space I would be brought,

title: Sonnet XLIV
line: From limits far remote where thou dost stay.

title: Sonnet XLIV
line: No matter then although my foot did stand

title: Sonnet XLIV
line: Upon the farthest earth removed from thee;

title: Sonnet XLIV
line: For nimble thought can jump both sea and land

title: Sonnet XLIV
line: As soon as think the place where he would be.

title: Sonnet XLIV
line: But ah! thought kills me that I am not thought,

title: Sonnet XLIV
line: To leap large lengths of miles when thou art gone,

title: Sonnet XLIV
line: But that so much of earth and water wrought

title: Sonnet XLIV
line: I must attend time's leisure with my moan,

title: Sonnet XLIV
line: Receiving nought by elements so slow

title: Sonnet XLIV
line: But heavy tears, badges of either's woe.

title: Sonnet XLV
line: The other two, slight air and purging fire,

title: Sonnet XLV
line: Are both with thee, wherever I abide;

title: Sonnet XLV
line: The first my thought, the other my desire,

title: Sonnet XLV
line: These present-absent with swift motion slide.

title: Sonnet XLV
line: For when these quicker elements are gone

title: Sonnet XLV
line: In tender embassy of love to thee,

title: Sonnet XLV
line: My life, being made of four, with two alone

title: Sonnet XLV
line: Sinks down to death, oppress'd with melancholy;

title: Sonnet XLV
line: Until life's composition be recured

title: Sonnet XLV
line: By those swift messengers return'd from thee,

title: Sonnet XLV
line: Who even but now come back again, assured

title: Sonnet XLV
line: Of thy fair health, recounting it to me:

title: Sonnet XLV
line: This told, I joy; but then no longer glad,

title: Sonnet XLV
line: I send them back again and straight grow sad.

title: Sonnet XLVI
line: Mine eye and heart are at a mortal war

title: Sonnet XLVI
line: How to divide the conquest of thy sight;

title: Sonnet XLVI
line: Mine eye my heart thy picture's sight would bar,

title: Sonnet XLVI
line: My heart mine eye the freedom of that right.

title: Sonnet XLVI
line: My heart doth plead that thou in him dost lie--

title: Sonnet XLVI
line: A closet never pierced with crystal eyes--

title: Sonnet XLVI
line: But the defendant doth that plea deny

title: Sonnet XLVI
line: And says in him thy fair appearance lies.

title: Sonnet XLVI
line: To 'cide this title is impanneled

title: Sonnet XLVI
line: A quest of thoughts, all tenants to the heart,

title: Sonnet XLVI
line: And by their verdict is determined

title: Sonnet XLVI
line: The clear eye's moiety and the dear heart's part:

title: Sonnet XLVI
line: As thus; mine eye's due is thy outward part,

title: Sonnet XLVI
line: And my heart's right thy inward love of heart.

title: Sonnet XLVII
line: Betwixt mine eye and heart a league is took,

title: Sonnet XLVII
line: And each doth good turns now unto the other:

title: Sonnet XLVII
line: When that mine eye is famish'd for a look,

title: Sonnet XLVII
line: Or heart in love with sighs himself doth smother,

title: Sonnet XLVII
line: With my love's picture then my eye doth feast

title: Sonnet XLVII
line: And to the painted banquet bids my heart;

title: Sonnet XLVII
line: Another time mine eye is my heart's guest

title: Sonnet XLVII
line: And in his thoughts of love doth share a part:

title: Sonnet XLVII
line: So, either by thy picture or my love,

title: Sonnet XLVII
line: Thyself away art resent still with me;

title: Sonnet XLVII
line: For thou not farther than my thoughts canst move,

title: Sonnet XLVII
line: And I am still with them and they with thee;

title: Sonnet XLVII
line: Or, if they sleep, thy picture in my sight

title: Sonnet XLVII
line: Awakes my heart to heart's and eye's delight.

title: Sonnet XLVIII
line: How careful was I, when I took my way,

title: Sonnet XLVIII
line: Each trifle under truest bars to thrust,

title: Sonnet XLVIII
line: That to my use it might unused stay

title: Sonnet XLVIII
line: From hands of falsehood, in sure wards of trust!

title: Sonnet XLVIII
line: But thou, to whom my jewels trifles are,

title: Sonnet XLVIII
line: Most worthy of comfort, now my greatest grief,

title: Sonnet XLVIII
line: Thou, best of dearest and mine only care,

title: Sonnet XLVIII
line: Art left the prey of every vulgar thief.

title: Sonnet XLVIII
line: Thee have I not lock'd up in any chest,

title: Sonnet XLVIII
line: Save where thou art not, though I feel thou art,

title: Sonnet XLVIII
line: Within the gentle closure of my breast,

title: Sonnet XLVIII
line: From whence at pleasure thou mayst come and part;

title: Sonnet XLVIII
line: And even thence thou wilt be stol'n, I fear,

title: Sonnet XLVIII
line: For truth proves thievish for a prize so dear.

title: Sonnet XLIX
line: Against that time, if ever that time come,

title: Sonnet XLIX
line: When I shall see thee frown on my defects,

title: Sonnet XLIX
line: When as thy love hath cast his utmost sum,

title: Sonnet XLIX
line: Call'd to that audit by advised respects;

title: Sonnet XLIX
line: Against that time when thou shalt strangely pass

title: Sonnet XLIX
line: And scarcely greet me with that sun thine eye,

title: Sonnet XLIX
line: When love, converted from the thing it was,

title: Sonnet XLIX
line: Shall reasons find of settled gravity,--

title: Sonnet XLIX
line: Against that time do I ensconce me here

title: Sonnet XLIX
line: Within the knowledge of mine own desert,

title: Sonnet XLIX
line: And this my hand against myself uprear,

title: Sonnet XLIX
line: To guard the lawful reasons on thy part:

title: Sonnet XLIX
line: To leave poor me thou hast the strength of laws,

title: Sonnet XLIX
line: Since why to love I can allege no cause.

title: Sonnet L
line: How heavy do I journey on the way,

title: Sonnet L
line: When what I seek, my weary travel's end,

title: Sonnet L
line: Doth teach that ease and that repose to say

title: Sonnet L
line: 'Thus far the miles are measured from thy friend!'

title: Sonnet L
line: The beast that bears me, tired with my woe,

title: Sonnet L
line: Plods dully on, to bear that weight in me,

title: Sonnet L
line: As if by some instinct the wretch did know

title: Sonnet L
line: His rider loved not speed, being made from thee:

title: Sonnet L
line: The bloody spur cannot provoke him on

title: Sonnet L
line: That sometimes anger thrusts into his hide;

title: Sonnet L
line: Which heavily he answers with a groan,

title: Sonnet L
line: More sharp to me than spurring to his side;

title: Sonnet L
line: For that same groan doth put this in my mind;

title: Sonnet L
line: My grief lies onward and my joy behind.

title: Sonnet LI
line: Thus can my love excuse the slow offence

title: Sonnet LI
line: Of my dull bearer when from thee I speed:

title: Sonnet LI
line: From where thou art why should I haste me thence?

title: Sonnet LI
line: Till I return, of posting is no need.

title: Sonnet LI
line: O, what excuse will my poor beast then find,

title: Sonnet LI
line: When swift extremity can seem but slow?

title: Sonnet LI
line: Then should I spur, though mounted on the wind;

title: Sonnet LI
line: In winged speed no motion shall I know:

title: Sonnet LI
line: Then can no horse with my desire keep pace;

title: Sonnet LI
line: Therefore desire of perfect'st love being made,

title: Sonnet LI
line: Shall neigh--no dull flesh--in his fiery race;

title: Sonnet LI
line: But love, for love, thus shall excuse my jade;

title: Sonnet LI
line: Since from thee going he went wilful-slow,

title: Sonnet LI
line: Towards thee I'll run, and give him leave to go.

title: Sonnet LII
line: So am I as the rich, whose blessed key

title: Sonnet LII
line: Can bring him to his sweet up-locked treasure,

title: Sonnet LII
line: The which he will not every hour survey,

title: Sonnet LII
line: For blunting the fine point of seldom pleasure.

title: Sonnet LII
line: Therefore are feasts so solemn and so rare,

title: Sonnet LII
line: Since, seldom coming, in the long year set,

title: Sonnet LII
line: Like stones of worth they thinly placed are,

title: Sonnet LII
line: Or captain jewels in the carcanet.

title: Sonnet LII
line: So is the time that keeps you as my chest,

title: Sonnet LII
line: Or as the wardrobe which the robe doth hide,

title: Sonnet LII
line: To make some special instant special blest,

title: Sonnet LII
line: By new unfolding his imprison'd pride.

title: Sonnet LII
line: Blessed are you, whose worthiness gives scope,

title: Sonnet LII
line: Being had, to triumph, being lack'd, to hope.

title: Sonnet LIII
line: What is your substance, whereof are you made,

title: Sonnet LIII
line: That millions of strange shadows on you tend?

title: Sonnet LIII
line: Since every one hath, every one, one shade,

title: Sonnet LIII
line: And you, but one, can every shadow lend.

title: Sonnet LIII
line: Describe Adonis, and the counterfeit

title: Sonnet LIII
line: Is poorly imitated after you;

title: Sonnet LIII
line: On Helen's cheek all art of beauty set,

title: Sonnet LIII
line: And you in Grecian tires are painted new:

title: Sonnet LIII
line: Speak of the spring and foison of the year;

title: Sonnet LIII
line: The one doth shadow of your beauty show,

title: Sonnet LIII
line: The other as your bounty doth appear;

title: Sonnet LIII
line: And you in every blessed shape we know.

title: Sonnet LIII
line: In all external grace you have some part,

title: Sonnet LIII
line: But you like none, none you, for constant heart.

title: Sonnet LIV
line: O, how much more doth beauty beauteous seem

title: Sonnet LIV
line: By that sweet ornament which truth doth give!

title: Sonnet LIV
line: The rose looks fair, but fairer we it deem

title: Sonnet LIV
line: For that sweet odour which doth in it live.

title: Sonnet LIV
line: The canker-blooms have full as deep a dye

title: Sonnet LIV
line: As the perfumed tincture of the roses,

title: Sonnet LIV
line: Hang on such thorns and play as wantonly

title: Sonnet LIV
line: When summer's breath their masked buds discloses:

title: Sonnet LIV
line: But, for their virtue only is their show,

title: Sonnet LIV
line: They live unwoo'd and unrespected fade,

title: Sonnet LIV
line: Die to themselves. Sweet roses do not so;

title: Sonnet LIV
line: Of their sweet deaths are sweetest odours made:

title: Sonnet LIV
line: And so of you, beauteous and lovely youth,

title: Sonnet LIV
line: When that shall fade, my verse distills your truth.

title: Sonnet LV
line: Not marble, nor the gilded monuments

title: Sonnet LV
line: Of princes, shall outlive this powerful rhyme;

title: Sonnet LV
line: But you shall shine more bright in these contents

title: Sonnet LV
line: Than unswept stone besmear'd with sluttish time.

title: Sonnet LV
line: When wasteful war shall statues overturn,

title: Sonnet LV
line: And broils root out the work of masonry,

title: Sonnet LV
line: Nor Mars his sword nor war's quick fire shall burn

title: Sonnet LV
line: The living record of your memory.

title: Sonnet LV
line: 'Gainst death and all-oblivious enmity

title: Sonnet LV
line: Shall you pace forth; your praise shall still find room

title: Sonnet LV
line: Even in the eyes of all posterity

title: Sonnet LV
line: That wear this world out to the ending doom.

title: Sonnet LV
line: So, till the judgment that yourself arise,

title: Sonnet LV
line: You live in this, and dwell in lover's eyes.

title: Sonnet LVI
line: Sweet love, renew thy force; be it not said

title: Sonnet LVI
line: Thy edge should blunter be than appetite,

title: Sonnet LVI
line: Which but to-day by feeding is allay'd,

title: Sonnet LVI
line: To-morrow sharpen'd in his former might:

title: Sonnet LVI
line: So, love, be thou; although to-day thou fill

title: Sonnet LVI
line: Thy hungry eyes even till they wink with fullness,

title: Sonnet LVI
line: To-morrow see again, and do not kill

title: Sonnet LVI
line: The spirit of love with a perpetual dullness.

title: Sonnet LVI
line: Let this sad interim like the ocean be

title: Sonnet LVI
line: Which parts the shore, where two contracted new

title: Sonnet LVI
line: Come daily to the banks, that, when they see

title: Sonnet LVI
line: Return of love, more blest may be the view;

title: Sonnet LVI
line: Else call it winter, which being full of care

title: Sonnet LVI
line: Makes summer's welcome thrice more wish'd, more rare.

title: Sonnet LVII
line: Being your slave, what should I do but tend

title: Sonnet LVII
line: Upon the hours and times of your desire?

title: Sonnet LVII
line: I have no precious time at all to spend,

title: Sonnet LVII
line: Nor services to do, till you require.

title: Sonnet LVII
line: Nor dare I chide the world-without-end hour

title: Sonnet LVII
line: Whilst I, my sovereign, watch the clock for you,

title: Sonnet LVII
line: Nor think the bitterness of absence sour

title: Sonnet LVII
line: When you have bid your servant once adieu;

title: Sonnet LVII
line: Nor dare I question with my jealous thought

title: Sonnet LVII
line: Where you may be, or your affairs suppose,

title: Sonnet LVII
line: But, like a sad slave, stay and think of nought

title: Sonnet LVII
line: Save, where you are how happy you make those.

title: Sonnet LVII
line: So true a fool is love that in your will,

title: Sonnet LVII
line: Though you do any thing, he thinks no ill.

title: Sonnet LVIII
line: That god forbid that made me first your slave,

title: Sonnet LVIII
line: I should in thought control your times of pleasure,

title: Sonnet LVIII
line: Or at your hand the account of hours to crave,

title: Sonnet LVIII
line: Being your vassal, bound to stay your leisure!

title: Sonnet LVIII
line: O, let me suffer, being at your beck,

title: Sonnet LVIII
line: The imprison'd absence of your liberty;

title: Sonnet LVIII
line: And patience, tame to sufferance, bide each cheque,

title: Sonnet LVIII
line: Without accusing you of injury.

title: Sonnet LVIII
line: Be where you list, your charter is so strong

title: Sonnet LVIII
line: That you yourself may privilege your time

title: Sonnet LVIII
line: To what you will; to you it doth belong

title: Sonnet LVIII
line: Yourself to pardon of self-doing crime.

title: Sonnet LVIII
line: I am to wait, though waiting so be hell;

title: Sonnet LVIII
line: Not blame your pleasure, be it ill or well.

title: Sonnet LIX
line: If there be nothing new, but that which is

title: Sonnet LIX
line: Hath been before, how are our brains beguiled,

title: Sonnet LIX
line: Which, labouring for invention, bear amiss

title: Sonnet LIX
line: The second burden of a former child!

title: Sonnet LIX
line: O, that record could with a backward look,

title: Sonnet LIX
line: Even of five hundred courses of the sun,

title: Sonnet LIX
line: Show me your image in some antique book,

title: Sonnet LIX
line: Since mind at first in character was done!

title: Sonnet LIX
line: That I might see what the old world could say

title: Sonnet LIX
line: To this composed wonder of your frame;

title: Sonnet LIX
line: Whether we are mended, or whether better they,

title: Sonnet LIX
line: Or whether revolution be the same.

title: Sonnet LIX
line: O, sure I am, the wits of former days

title: Sonnet LIX
line: To subjects worse have given admiring praise.

title: Sonnet LX
line: Like as the waves make towards the pebbled shore,

title: Sonnet LX
line: So do our minutes hasten to their end;

title: Sonnet LX
line: Each changing place with that which goes before,

title: Sonnet LX
line: In sequent toil all forwards do contend.

title: Sonnet LX
line: Nativity, once in the main of light,

title: Sonnet LX
line: Crawls to maturity, wherewith being crown'd,

title: Sonnet LX
line: Crooked elipses 'gainst his glory fight,

title: Sonnet LX
line: And Time that gave doth now his gift confound.

title: Sonnet LX
line: Time doth transfix the flourish set on youth

title: Sonnet LX
line: And delves the parallels in beauty's brow,

title: Sonnet LX
line: Feeds on the rarities of nature's truth,

title: Sonnet LX
line: And nothing stands but for his scythe to mow:

title: Sonnet LX
line: And yet to times in hope my verse shall stand,

title: Sonnet LX
line: Praising thy worth, despite his cruel hand.

title: Sonnet LXI
line: Is it thy will thy image should keep open

title: Sonnet LXI
line: My heavy eyelids to the weary night?

title: Sonnet LXI
line: Dost thou desire my slumbers should be broken,

title: Sonnet LXI
line: While shadows like to thee do mock my sight?

title: Sonnet LXI
line: Is it thy spirit that thou send'st from thee

title: Sonnet LXI
line: So far from home into my deeds to pry,

title: Sonnet LXI
line: To find out shames and idle hours in me,

title: Sonnet LXI
line: The scope and tenor of thy jealousy?

title: Sonnet LXI
line: O, no! thy love, though much, is not so great:

title: Sonnet LXI
line: It is my love that keeps mine eye awake;

title: Sonnet LXI
line: Mine own true love that doth my rest defeat,

title: Sonnet LXI
line: To play the watchman ever for thy sake:

title: Sonnet LXI
line: For thee watch I whilst thou dost wake elsewhere,

title: Sonnet LXI
line: From me far off, with others all too near.

title: Sonnet LXII
line: Sin of self-love possesseth all mine eye

title: Sonnet LXII
line: And all my soul and all my every part;

title: Sonnet LXII
line: And for this sin there is no remedy,

title: Sonnet LXII
line: It is so grounded inward in my heart.

title: Sonnet LXII
line: Methinks no face so gracious is as mine,

title: Sonnet LXII
line: No shape so true, no truth of such account;

title: Sonnet LXII
line: And for myself mine own worth do define,

title: Sonnet LXII
line: As I all other in all worths surmount.

title: Sonnet LXII
line: But when my glass shows me myself indeed,

title: Sonnet LXII
line: Beated and chopp'd with tann'd antiquity,

title: Sonnet LXII
line: Mine own self-love quite contrary I read;

title: Sonnet LXII
line: Self so self-loving were iniquity.

title: Sonnet LXII
line: 'Tis thee, myself, that for myself I praise,

title: Sonnet LXII
line: Painting my age with beauty of thy days.

title: Sonnet LXIII
line: Against my love shall be, as I am now,

title: Sonnet LXIII
line: With Time's injurious hand crush'd and o'er-worn;

title: Sonnet LXIII
line: When hours have drain'd his blood and fill'd his brow

title: Sonnet LXIII
line: With lines and wrinkles; when his youthful morn

title: Sonnet LXIII
line: Hath travell'd on to age's steepy night,

title: Sonnet LXIII
line: And all those beauties whereof now he's king

title: Sonnet LXIII
line: Are vanishing or vanish'd out of sight,

title: Sonnet LXIII
line: Stealing away the treasure of his spring;

title: Sonnet LXIII
line: For such a time do I now fortify

title: Sonnet LXIII
line: Against confounding age's cruel knife,

title: Sonnet LXIII
line: That he shall never cut from memory

title: Sonnet LXIII
line: My sweet love's beauty, though my lover's life:

title: Sonnet LXIII
line: His beauty shall in these black lines be seen,

title: Sonnet LXIII
line: And they shall live, and he in them still green.

title: Sonnet LXIV
line: When I have seen by Time's fell hand defaced

title: Sonnet LXIV
line: The rich proud cost of outworn buried age;

title: Sonnet LXIV
line: When sometime lofty towers I see down-razed

title: Sonnet LXIV
line: And brass eternal slave to mortal rage;

title: Sonnet LXIV
line: When I have seen the hungry ocean gain

title: Sonnet LXIV
line: Advantage on the kingdom of the shore,

title: Sonnet LXIV
line: And the firm soil win of the watery main,

title: Sonnet LXIV
line: Increasing store with loss and loss with store;

title: Sonnet LXIV
line: When I have seen such interchange of state,

title: Sonnet LXIV
line: Or state itself confounded to decay;

title: Sonnet LXIV
line: Ruin hath taught me thus to ruminate,

title: Sonnet LXIV
line: That Time will come and take my love away.

title: Sonnet LXIV
line: This thought is as a death, which cannot choose

title: Sonnet LXIV
line: But weep to have that which it fears to lose.

title: Sonnet LXV
line: Since brass, nor stone, nor earth, nor boundless sea,

title: Sonnet LXV
line: But sad mortality o'er-sways their power,

title: Sonnet LXV
line: How with this rage shall beauty hold a plea,

title: Sonnet LXV
line: Whose action is no stronger than a flower?

title: Sonnet LXV
line: O, how shall summer's honey breath hold out

title: Sonnet LXV
line: Against the wreckful siege of battering days,

title: Sonnet LXV
line: When rocks impregnable are not so stout,

title: Sonnet LXV
line: Nor gates of steel so strong, but Time decays?

title: Sonnet LXV
line: O fearful meditation! where, alack,

title: Sonnet LXV
line: Shall Time's best jewel from Time's chest lie hid?

title: Sonnet LXV
line: Or what strong hand can hold his swift foot back?

title: Sonnet LXV
line: Or who his spoil of beauty can forbid?

title: Sonnet LXV
line: O, none, unless this miracle have might,

title: Sonnet LXV
line: That in black ink my love may still shine bright.

title: Sonnet LXVI
line: Tired with all these, for restful death I cry,

title: Sonnet LXVI
line: As, to behold desert a beggar born,

title: Sonnet LXVI
line: And needy nothing trimm'd in jollity,

title: Sonnet LXVI
line: And purest faith unhappily forsworn,

title: Sonnet LXVI
line: And guilded honour shamefully misplaced,

title: Sonnet LXVI
line: And maiden virtue rudely strumpeted,

title: Sonnet LXVI
line: And right perfection wrongfully disgraced,

title: Sonnet LXVI
line: And strength by limping sway disabled,

title: Sonnet LXVI
line: And art made tongue-tied by authority,

title: Sonnet LXVI
line: And folly doctor-like controlling skill,

title: Sonnet LXVI
line: And simple truth miscall'd simplicity,

title: Sonnet LXVI
line: And captive good attending captain ill:

title: Sonnet LXVI
line: Tired with all these, from these would I be gone,

title: Sonnet LXVI
line: Save that, to die, I leave my love alone.

title: Sonnet LXVII
line: Ah! wherefore with infection should he live,

title: Sonnet LXVII
line: And with his presence grace impiety,

title: Sonnet LXVII
line: That sin by him advantage should achieve

title: Sonnet LXVII
line: And lace itself with his society?

title: Sonnet LXVII
line: Why should false painting imitate his cheek

title: Sonnet LXVII
line: And steal dead seeing of his living hue?

title: Sonnet LXVII
line: Why should poor beauty indirectly seek

title: Sonnet LXVII
line: Roses of shadow, since his rose is true?

title: Sonnet LXVII
line: Why should he live, now Nature bankrupt is,

title: Sonnet LXVII
line: Beggar'd of blood to blush through lively veins?

title: Sonnet LXVII
line: For she hath no exchequer now but his,

title: Sonnet LXVII
line: And, proud of many, lives upon his gains.

title: Sonnet LXVII
line: O, him she stores, to show what wealth she had

title: Sonnet LXVII
line: In days long since, before these last so bad.

title: Sonnet LXVIII
line: Thus is his cheek the map of days outworn,

title: Sonnet LXVIII
line: When beauty lived and died as flowers do now,

title: Sonnet LXVIII
line: Before the bastard signs of fair were born,

title: Sonnet LXVIII
line: Or durst inhabit on a living brow;

title: Sonnet LXVIII
line: Before the golden tresses of the dead,

title: Sonnet LXVIII
line: The right of sepulchres, were shorn away,

title: Sonnet LXVIII
line: To live a second life on second head;

title: Sonnet LXVIII
line: Ere beauty's dead fleece made another gay:

title: Sonnet LXVIII
line: In him those holy antique hours are seen,

title: Sonnet LXVIII
line: Without all ornament, itself and true,

title: Sonnet LXVIII
line: Making no summer of another's green,

title: Sonnet LXVIII
line: Robbing no old to dress his beauty new;

title: Sonnet LXVIII
line: And him as for a map doth Nature store,

title: Sonnet LXVIII
line: To show false Art what beauty was of yore.

title: Sonnet LXIX
line: Those parts of thee that the world's eye doth view

title: Sonnet LXIX
line: Want nothing that the thought of hearts can mend;

title: Sonnet LXIX
line: All tongues, the voice of souls, give thee that due,

title: Sonnet LXIX
line: Uttering bare truth, even so as foes commend.

title: Sonnet LXIX
line: Thy outward thus with outward praise is crown'd;

title: Sonnet LXIX
line: But those same tongues that give thee so thine own

title: Sonnet LXIX
line: In other accents do this praise confound

title: Sonnet LXIX
line: By seeing farther than the eye hath shown.

title: Sonnet LXIX
line: They look into the beauty of thy mind,

title: Sonnet LXIX
line: And that, in guess, they measure by thy deeds;

title: Sonnet LXIX
line: Then, churls, their thoughts, although their eyes were kind,

title: Sonnet LXIX
line: To thy fair flower add the rank smell of weeds:

title: Sonnet LXIX
line: But why thy odour matcheth not thy show,

title: Sonnet LXIX
line: The solve is this, that thou dost common grow.

title: Sonnet LXX
line: That thou art blamed shall not be thy defect,

title: Sonnet LXX
line: For slander's mark was ever yet the fair;

title: Sonnet LXX
line: The ornament of beauty is suspect,

title: Sonnet LXX
line: A crow that flies in heaven's sweetest air.

title: Sonnet LXX
line: So thou be good, slander doth but approve

title: Sonnet LXX
line: Thy worth the greater, being woo'd of time;

title: Sonnet LXX
line: For canker vice the sweetest buds doth love,

title: Sonnet LXX
line: And thou present'st a pure unstained prime.

title: Sonnet LXX
line: Thou hast pass'd by the ambush of young days,

title: Sonnet LXX
line: Either not assail'd or victor being charged;

title: Sonnet LXX
line: Yet this thy praise cannot be so thy praise,

title: Sonnet LXX
line: To tie up envy evermore enlarged:

title: Sonnet LXX
line: If some suspect of ill mask'd not thy show,

title: Sonnet LXX
line: Then thou alone kingdoms of hearts shouldst owe.

title: Sonnet LXXI
line: No longer mourn for me when I am dead

title: Sonnet LXXI
line: Then you shall hear the surly sullen bell

title: Sonnet LXXI
line: Give warning to the world that I am fled

title: Sonnet LXXI
line: From this vile world, with vilest worms to dwell:

title: Sonnet LXXI
line: Nay, if you read this line, remember not

title: Sonnet LXXI
line: The hand that writ it; for I love you so

title: Sonnet LXXI
line: That I in your sweet thoughts would be forgot

title: Sonnet LXXI
line: If thinking on me then should make you woe.

title: Sonnet LXXI
line: O, if, I say, you look upon this verse

title: Sonnet LXXI
line: When I perhaps compounded am with clay,

title: Sonnet LXXI
line: Do not so much as my poor name rehearse.

title: Sonnet LXXI
line: But let your love even with my life decay,

title: Sonnet LXXI
line: Lest the wise world should look into your moan

title: Sonnet LXXI
line: And mock you with me after I am gone.

title: Sonnet LXXII
line: O, lest the world should task you to recite

title: Sonnet LXXII
line: What merit lived in me, that you should love

title: Sonnet LXXII
line: After my death, dear love, forget me quite,

title: Sonnet LXXII
line: For you in me can nothing worthy prove;

title: Sonnet LXXII
line: Unless you would devise some virtuous lie,

title: Sonnet LXXII
line: To do more for me than mine own desert,

title: Sonnet LXXII
line: And hang more praise upon deceased I

title: Sonnet LXXII
line: Than niggard truth would willingly impart:

title: Sonnet LXXII
line: O, lest your true love may seem false in this,

title: Sonnet LXXII
line: That you for love speak well of me untrue,

title: Sonnet LXXII
line: My name be buried where my body is,

title: Sonnet LXXII
line: And live no more to shame nor me nor you.

title: Sonnet LXXII
line: For I am shamed by that which I bring forth,

title: Sonnet LXXII
line: And so should you, to love things nothing worth.

title: Sonnet LXXIII
line: That time of year thou mayst in me behold

title: Sonnet LXXIII
line: When yellow leaves, or none, or few, do hang

title: Sonnet LXXIII
line: Upon those boughs which shake against the cold,

title: Sonnet LXXIII
line: Bare ruin'd choirs, where late the sweet birds sang.

title: Sonnet LXXIII
line: In me thou seest the twilight of such day

title: Sonnet LXXIII
line: As after sunset fadeth in the west,

title: Sonnet LXXIII
line: Which by and by black night doth take away,

title: Sonnet LXXIII
line: Death's second self, that seals up all in rest.

title: Sonnet LXXIII
line: In me thou see'st the glowing of such fire

title: Sonnet LXXIII
line: That on the ashes of his youth doth lie,

title: Sonnet LXXIII
line: As the death-bed whereon it must expire

title: Sonnet LXXIII
line: Consumed with that which it was nourish'd by.

title: Sonnet LXXIII
line: This thou perceivest, which makes thy love more strong,

title: Sonnet LXXIII
line: To love that well which thou must leave ere long.

title: Sonnet LXXIV
line: But be contented: when that fell arrest

title: Sonnet LXXIV
line: Without all bail shall carry me away,

title: Sonnet LXXIV
line: My life hath in this line some interest,

title: Sonnet LXXIV
line: Which for memorial still with thee shall stay.

title: Sonnet LXXIV
line: When thou reviewest this, thou dost review

title: Sonnet LXXIV
line: The very part was consecrate to thee:

title: Sonnet LXXIV
line: The earth can have but earth, which is his due;

title: Sonnet LXXIV
line: My spirit is thine, the better part of me:

title: Sonnet LXXIV
line: So then thou hast but lost the dregs of life,

title: Sonnet LXXIV
line: The prey of worms, my body being dead,

title: Sonnet LXXIV
line: The coward conquest of a wretch's knife,

title: Sonnet LXXIV
line: Too base of thee to be remembered.

title: Sonnet LXXIV
line: The worth of that is that which it contains,

title: Sonnet LXXIV
line: And that is this, and this with thee remains.

title: Sonnet LXXV
line: So are you to my thoughts as food to life,

title: Sonnet LXXV
line: Or as sweet-season'd showers are to the ground;

title: Sonnet LXXV
line: And for the peace of you I hold such strife

title: Sonnet LXXV
line: As 'twixt a miser and his wealth is found;

title: Sonnet LXXV
line: Now proud as an enjoyer and anon

title: Sonnet LXXV
line: Doubting the filching age will steal his treasure,

title: Sonnet LXXV
line: Now counting best to be with you alone,

title: Sonnet LXXV
line: Then better'd that the world may see my pleasure;

title: Sonnet LXXV
line: Sometime all full with feasting on your sight

title: Sonnet LXXV
line: And by and by clean starved for a look;

title: Sonnet LXXV
line: Possessing or pursuing no delight,

title: Sonnet LXXV
line: Save what is had or must from you be took.

title: Sonnet LXXV
line: Thus do I pine and surfeit day by day,

title: Sonnet LXXV
line: Or gluttoning on all, or all away.

title: Sonnet LXXVI
line: Why is my verse so barren of new pride,

title: Sonnet LXXVI
line: So far from variation or quick change?

title: Sonnet LXXVI
line: Why with the time do I not glance aside

title: Sonnet LXXVI
line: To new-found methods and to compounds strange?

title: Sonnet LXXVI
line: Why write I still all one, ever the same,

title: Sonnet LXXVI
line: And keep invention in a noted weed,

title: Sonnet LXXVI
line: That every word doth almost tell my name,

title: Sonnet LXXVI
line: Showing their birth and where they did proceed?

title: Sonnet LXXVI
line: O, know, sweet love, I always write of you,

title: Sonnet LXXVI
line: And you and love are still my argument;

title: Sonnet LXXVI
line: So all my best is dressing old words new,

title: Sonnet LXXVI
line: Spending again what is already spent:

title: Sonnet LXXVI
line: For as the sun is daily new and old,

title: Sonnet LXXVI
line: So is my love still telling what is told.

title: Sonnet LXXVII
line: Thy glass will show thee how thy beauties wear,

title: Sonnet LXXVII
line: Thy dial how thy precious minutes waste;

title: Sonnet LXXVII
line: The vacant leaves thy mind's imprint will bear,

title: Sonnet LXXVII
line: And of this book this learning mayst thou taste.

title: Sonnet LXXVII
line: The wrinkles which thy glass will truly show

title: Sonnet LXXVII
line: Of mouthed graves will give thee memory;

title: Sonnet LXXVII
line: Thou by thy dial's shady stealth mayst know

title: Sonnet LXXVII
line: Time's thievish progress to eternity.

title: Sonnet LXXVII
line: Look, what thy memory can not contain

title: Sonnet LXXVII
line: Commit to these waste blanks, and thou shalt find

title: Sonnet LXXVII
line: Those children nursed, deliver'd from thy brain,

title: Sonnet LXXVII
line: To take a new acquaintance of thy mind.

title: Sonnet LXXVII
line: These offices, so oft as thou wilt look,

title: Sonnet LXXVII
line: Shall profit thee and much enrich thy book.

title: Sonnet LXXVIII
line: So oft have I invoked thee for my Muse

title: Sonnet LXXVIII
line: And found such fair assistance in my verse

title: Sonnet LXXVIII
line: As every alien pen hath got my use

title: Sonnet LXXVIII
line: And under thee their poesy disperse.

title: Sonnet LXXVIII
line: Thine eyes that taught the dumb on high to sing

title: Sonnet LXXVIII
line: And heavy ignorance aloft to fly

title: Sonnet LXXVIII
line: Have added feathers to the learned's wing

title: Sonnet LXXVIII
line: And given grace a double majesty.

title: Sonnet LXXVIII
line: Yet be most proud of that which I compile,

title: Sonnet LXXVIII
line: Whose influence is thine and born of thee:

title: Sonnet LXXVIII
line: In others' works thou dost but mend the style,

title: Sonnet LXXVIII
line: And arts with thy sweet graces graced be;

title: Sonnet LXXVIII
line: But thou art all my art and dost advance

title: Sonnet LXXVIII
line: As high as learning my rude ignorance.

title: Sonnet LXXIX
line: Whilst I alone did call upon thy aid,

title: Sonnet LXXIX
line: My verse alone had all thy gentle grace,

title: Sonnet LXXIX
line: But now my gracious numbers are decay'd

title: Sonnet LXXIX
line: And my sick Muse doth give another place.

title: Sonnet LXXIX
line: I grant, sweet love, thy lovely argument

title: Sonnet LXXIX
line: Deserves the travail of a worthier pen,

title: Sonnet LXXIX
line: Yet what of thee thy poet doth invent

title: Sonnet LXXIX
line: He robs thee of and pays it thee again.

title: Sonnet LXXIX
line: He lends thee virtue and he stole that word

title: Sonnet LXXIX
line: From thy behavior; beauty doth he give

title: Sonnet LXXIX
line: And found it in thy cheek; he can afford

title: Sonnet LXXIX
line: No praise to thee but what in thee doth live.

title: Sonnet LXXIX
line: Then thank him not for that which he doth say,

title: Sonnet LXXIX
line: Since what he owes thee thou thyself dost pay.

title: Sonnet LXXX
line: O, how I faint when I of you do write,

title: Sonnet LXXX
line: Knowing a better spirit doth use your name,

title: Sonnet LXXX
line: And in the praise thereof spends all his might,

title: Sonnet LXXX
line: To make me tongue-tied, speaking of your fame!

title: Sonnet LXXX
line: But since your worth, wide as the ocean is,

title: Sonnet LXXX
line: The humble as the proudest sail doth bear,

title: Sonnet LXXX
line: My saucy bark inferior far to his

title: Sonnet LXXX
line: On your broad main doth wilfully appear.

title: Sonnet LXXX
line: Your shallowest help will hold me up afloat,

title: Sonnet LXXX
line: Whilst he upon your soundless deep doth ride;

title: Sonnet LXXX
line: Or being wreck'd, I am a worthless boat,

title: Sonnet LXXX
line: He of tall building and of goodly pride:

title: Sonnet LXXX
line: Then if he thrive and I be cast away,

title: Sonnet LXXX
line: The worst was this; my love was my decay.

title: Sonnet LXXXI
line: Or I shall live your epitaph to make,

title: Sonnet LXXXI
line: Or you survive when I in earth am rotten;

title: Sonnet LXXXI
line: From hence your memory death cannot take,

title: Sonnet LXXXI
line: Although in me each part will be forgotten.

title: Sonnet LXXXI
line: Your name from hence immortal life shall have,

title: Sonnet LXXXI
line: Though I, once gone, to all the world must die:

title: Sonnet LXXXI
line: The earth can yield me but a common grave,

title: Sonnet LXXXI
line: When you entombed in men's eyes shall lie.

title: Sonnet LXXXI
line: Your monument shall be my gentle verse,

title: Sonnet LXXXI
line: Which eyes not yet created shall o'er-read,

title: Sonnet LXXXI
line: And tongues to be your being shall rehearse

title: Sonnet LXXXI
line: When all the breathers of this world are dead;

title: Sonnet LXXXI
line: You still shall live--such virtue hath my pen--

title: Sonnet LXXXI
line: Where breath most breathes, even in the mouths of men.

title: Sonnet LXXXII
line: I grant thou wert not married to my Muse

title: Sonnet LXXXII
line: And therefore mayst without attaint o'erlook

title: Sonnet LXXXII
line: The dedicated words which writers use

title: Sonnet LXXXII
line: Of their fair subject, blessing every book

title: Sonnet LXXXII
line: Thou art as fair in knowledge as in hue,

title: Sonnet LXXXII
line: Finding thy worth a limit past my praise,

title: Sonnet LXXXII
line: And therefore art enforced to seek anew

title: Sonnet LXXXII
line: Some fresher stamp of the time-bettering days

title: Sonnet LXXXII
line: And do so, love; yet when they have devised

title: Sonnet LXXXII
line: What strained touches rhetoric can lend,

title: Sonnet LXXXII
line: Thou truly fair wert truly sympathized

title: Sonnet LXXXII
line: In true plain words by thy true-telling friend;

title: Sonnet LXXXII
line: And their gross painting might be better used

title: Sonnet LXXXII
line: Where cheeks need blood; in thee it is abused.

title: Sonnet LXXXIII
line: I never saw that you did painting need

title: Sonnet LXXXIII
line: And therefore to your fair no painting set;

title: Sonnet LXXXIII
line: I found, or thought I found, you did exceed

title: Sonnet LXXXIII
line: The barren tender of a poet's debt;

title: Sonnet LXXXIII
line: And therefore have I slept in your report,
