title: Sonnet LXXXIII
line: That you yourself being extant well might show

title: Sonnet LXXXIII
line: How far a modern quill doth come too short,

title: Sonnet LXXXIII
line: Speaking of worth, what worth in you doth grow.

title: Sonnet LXXXIII
line: This silence for my sin you did impute,

title: Sonnet LXXXIII
line: Which shall be most my glory, being dumb;

title: Sonnet LXXXIII
line: For I impair not beauty being mute,

title: Sonnet LXXXIII
line: When others would give life and bring a tomb.

title: Sonnet LXXXIII
line: There lives more life in one of your fair eyes

title: Sonnet LXXXIII
line: Than both your poets can in praise devise.

title: Sonnet LXXXIV
line: Who is it that says most? which can say more

title: Sonnet LXXXIV
line: Than this rich praise, that you alone are you?

title: Sonnet LXXXIV
line: In whose confine immured is the store

title: Sonnet LXXXIV
line: Which should example where your equal grew.

title: Sonnet LXXXIV
line: Lean penury within that pen doth dwell

title: Sonnet LXXXIV
line: That to his subject lends not some small glory;

title: Sonnet LXXXIV
line: But he that writes of you, if he can tell

title: Sonnet LXXXIV
line: That you are you, so dignifies his story,

title: Sonnet LXXXIV
line: Let him but copy what in you is writ,

title: Sonnet LXXXIV
line: Not making worse what nature made so clear,

title: Sonnet LXXXIV
line: And such a counterpart shall fame his wit,

title: Sonnet LXXXIV
line: Making his style admired every where.

title: Sonnet LXXXIV
line: You to your beauteous blessings add a curse,

title: Sonnet LXXXIV
line: Being fond on praise, which makes your praises worse.

title: Sonnet LXXXV
line: My tongue-tied Muse in manners holds her still,

title: Sonnet LXXXV
line: While comments of your praise, richly compiled,

title: Sonnet LXXXV
line: Reserve their character with golden quill

title: Sonnet LXXXV
line: And precious phrase by all the Muses filed.

title: Sonnet LXXXV
line: I think good thoughts whilst other write good words,

title: Sonnet LXXXV
line: And like unletter'd clerk still cry 'Amen'

title: Sonnet LXXXV
line: To every hymn that able spirit affords

title: Sonnet LXXXV
line: In polish'd form of well-refined pen.

title: Sonnet LXXXV
line: Hearing you praised, I say ''Tis so, 'tis true,'

title: Sonnet LXXXV
line: And to the most of praise add something more;

title: Sonnet LXXXV
line: But that is in my thought, whose love to you,

title: Sonnet LXXXV
line: Though words come hindmost, holds his rank before.

title: Sonnet LXXXV
line: Then others for the breath of words respect,

title: Sonnet LXXXV
line: Me for my dumb thoughts, speaking in effect.

title: Sonnet LXXXVI
line: Was it the proud full sail of his great verse,

title: Sonnet LXXXVI
line: Bound for the prize of all too precious you,

title: Sonnet LXXXVI
line: That did my ripe thoughts in my brain inhearse,

title: Sonnet LXXXVI
line: Making their tomb the womb wherein they grew?

title: Sonnet LXXXVI
line: Was it his spirit, by spirits taught to write

title: Sonnet LXXXVI
line: Above a mortal pitch, that struck me dead?

title: Sonnet LXXXVI
line: No, neither he, nor his compeers by night

title: Sonnet LXXXVI
line: Giving him aid, my verse astonished.

title: Sonnet LXXXVI
line: He, nor that affable familiar ghost

title: Sonnet LXXXVI
line: Which nightly gulls him with intelligence

title: Sonnet LXXXVI
line: As victors of my silence cannot boast;

title: Sonnet LXXXVI
line: I was not sick of any fear from thence:

title: Sonnet LXXXVI
line: But when your countenance fill'd up his line,

title: Sonnet LXXXVI
line: Then lack'd I matter; that enfeebled mine.

title: Sonnet LXXXVII
line: Farewell! thou art too dear for my possessing,

title: Sonnet LXXXVII
line: And like enough thou know'st thy estimate:

title: Sonnet LXXXVII
line: The charter of thy worth gives thee releasing;

title: Sonnet LXXXVII
line: My bonds in thee are all determinate.

title: Sonnet LXXXVII
line: For how do I hold thee but by thy granting?

title: Sonnet LXXXVII
line: And for that riches where is my deserving?

title: Sonnet LXXXVII
line: The cause of this fair gift in me is wanting,

title: Sonnet LXXXVII
line: And so my patent back again is swerving.

title: Sonnet LXXXVII
line: Thyself thou gavest, thy own worth then not knowing,

title: Sonnet LXXXVII
line: Or me, to whom thou gavest it, else mistaking;

title: Sonnet LXXXVII
line: So thy great gift, upon misprision growing,

title: Sonnet LXXXVII
line: Comes home again, on better judgment making.

title: Sonnet LXXXVII
line: Thus have I had thee, as a dream doth flatter,

title: Sonnet LXXXVII
line: In sleep a king, but waking no such matter.

title: Sonnet LXXXVIII
line: When thou shalt be disposed to set me light,

title: Sonnet LXXXVIII
line: And place my merit in the eye of scorn,

title: Sonnet LXXXVIII
line: Upon thy side against myself I'll fight,

title: Sonnet LXXXVIII
line: And prove thee virtuous, though thou art forsworn.

title: Sonnet LXXXVIII
line: With mine own weakness being best acquainted,

title: Sonnet LXXXVIII
line: Upon thy part I can set down a story

title: Sonnet LXXXVIII
line: Of faults conceal'd, wherein I am attainted,

title: Sonnet LXXXVIII
line: That thou in losing me shalt win much glory:

title: Sonnet LXXXVIII
line: And I by this will be a gainer too;

title: Sonnet LXXXVIII
line: For bending all my loving thoughts on thee,

title: Sonnet LXXXVIII
line: The injuries that to myself I do,

title: Sonnet LXXXVIII
line: Doing thee vantage, double-vantage me.

title: Sonnet LXXXVIII
line: Such is my love, to thee I so belong,

title: Sonnet LXXXVIII
line: That for thy right myself will bear all wrong.

title: Sonnet LXXXIX
line: Say that thou didst forsake me for some fault,

title: Sonnet LXXXIX
line: And I will comment upon that offence;

title: Sonnet LXXXIX
line: Speak of my lameness, and I straight will halt,

title: Sonnet LXXXIX
line: Against thy reasons making no defence.

title: Sonnet LXXXIX
line: Thou canst not, love, disgrace me half so ill,

title: Sonnet LXXXIX
line: To set a form upon desired change,

title: Sonnet LXXXIX
line: As I'll myself disgrace: knowing thy will,

title: Sonnet LXXXIX
line: I will acquaintance strangle and look strange,

title: Sonnet LXXXIX
line: Be absent from thy walks, and in my tongue

title: Sonnet LXXXIX
line: Thy sweet beloved name no more shall dwell,

title: Sonnet LXXXIX
line: Lest I, too much profane, should do it wrong

title: Sonnet LXXXIX
line: And haply of our old acquaintance tell.

title: Sonnet LXXXIX
line: For thee against myself I'll vow debate,

title: Sonnet LXXXIX
line: For I must ne'er love him whom thou dost hate.

title: Sonnet XC
line: Then hate me when thou wilt; if ever, now;

title: Sonnet XC
line: Now, while the world is bent my deeds to cross,

title: Sonnet XC
line: Join with the spite of fortune, make me bow,

title: Sonnet XC
line: And do not drop in for an after-loss:

title: Sonnet XC
line: Ah, do not, when my heart hath 'scoped this sorrow,

title: Sonnet XC
line: Come in the rearward of a conquer'd woe;

title: Sonnet XC
line: Give not a windy night a rainy morrow,

title: Sonnet XC
line: To linger out a purposed overthrow.

title: Sonnet XC
line: If thou wilt leave me, do not leave me last,

title: Sonnet XC
line: When other petty griefs have done their spite

title: Sonnet XC
line: But in the onset come; so shall I taste

title: Sonnet XC
line: At first the very worst of fortune's might,

title: Sonnet XC
line: And other strains of woe, which now seem woe,

title: Sonnet XC
line: Compared with loss of thee will not seem so.

title: Sonnet XCI
line: Some glory in their birth, some in their skill,

title: Sonnet XCI
line: Some in their wealth, some in their bodies' force,

title: Sonnet XCI
line: Some in their garments, though new-fangled ill,

title: Sonnet XCI
line: Some in their hawks and hounds, some in their horse;

title: Sonnet XCI
line: And every humour hath his adjunct pleasure,

title: Sonnet XCI
line: Wherein it finds a joy above the rest:

title: Sonnet XCI
line: But these particulars are not my measure;

title: Sonnet XCI
line: All these I better in one general best.

title: Sonnet XCI
line: Thy love is better than high birth to me,

title: Sonnet XCI
line: Richer than wealth, prouder than garments' cost,

title: Sonnet XCI
line: Of more delight than hawks or horses be;

title: Sonnet XCI
line: And having thee, of all men's pride I boast:

title: Sonnet XCI
line: Wretched in this alone, that thou mayst take

title: Sonnet XCI
line: All this away and me most wretched make.

title: Sonnet XCII
line: But do thy worst to steal thyself away,

title: Sonnet XCII
line: For term of life thou art assured mine,

title: Sonnet XCII
line: And life no longer than thy love will stay,

title: Sonnet XCII
line: For it depends upon that love of thine.

title: Sonnet XCII
line: Then need I not to fear the worst of wrongs,

title: Sonnet XCII
line: When in the least of them my life hath end.

title: Sonnet XCII
line: I see a better state to me belongs

title: Sonnet XCII
line: Than that which on thy humour doth depend;

title: Sonnet XCII
line: Thou canst not vex me with inconstant mind,

title: Sonnet XCII
line: Since that my life on thy revolt doth lie.

title: Sonnet XCII
line: O, what a happy title do I find,

title: Sonnet XCII
line: Happy to have thy love, happy to die!

title: Sonnet XCII
line: But what's so blessed-fair that fears no blot?

title: Sonnet XCII
line: Thou mayst be false, and yet I know it not.

title: Sonnet XCIII
line: So shall I live, supposing thou art true,

title: Sonnet XCIII
line: Like a deceived husband; so love's face

title: Sonnet XCIII
line: May still seem love to me, though alter'd new;

title: Sonnet XCIII
line: Thy looks with me, thy heart in other place:

title: Sonnet XCIII
line: For there can live no hatred in thine eye,

title: Sonnet XCIII
line: Therefore in that I cannot know thy change.

title: Sonnet XCIII
line: In many's looks the false heart's history

title: Sonnet XCIII
line: Is writ in moods and frowns and wrinkles strange,

title: Sonnet XCIII
line: But heaven in thy creation did decree

title: Sonnet XCIII
line: That in thy face sweet love should ever dwell;

title: Sonnet XCIII
line: Whate'er thy thoughts or thy heart's workings be,

title: Sonnet XCIII
line: Thy looks should nothing thence but sweetness tell.

title: Sonnet XCIII
line: How like Eve's apple doth thy beauty grow,

title: Sonnet XCIII
line: if thy sweet virtue answer not thy show!

title: Sonnet XCIV
line: They that have power to hurt and will do none,

title: Sonnet XCIV
line: That do not do the thing they most do show,

title: Sonnet XCIV
line: Who, moving others, are themselves as stone,

title: Sonnet XCIV
line: Unmoved, cold, and to temptation slow,

title: Sonnet XCIV
line: They rightly do inherit heaven's graces

title: Sonnet XCIV
line: And husband nature's riches from expense;

title: Sonnet XCIV
line: They are the lords and owners of their faces,

title: Sonnet XCIV
line: Others but stewards of their excellence.

title: Sonnet XCIV
line: The summer's flower is to the summer sweet,

title: Sonnet XCIV
line: Though to itself it only live and die,

title: Sonnet XCIV
line: But if that flower with base infection meet,

title: Sonnet XCIV
line: The basest weed outbraves his dignity:

title: Sonnet XCIV
line: For sweetest things turn sourest by their deeds;

title: Sonnet XCIV
line: Lilies that fester smell far worse than weeds.

title: Sonnet XCV
line: How sweet and lovely dost thou make the shame

title: Sonnet XCV
line: Which, like a canker in the fragrant rose,

title: Sonnet XCV
line: Doth spot the beauty of thy budding name!

title: Sonnet XCV
line: O, in what sweets dost thou thy sins enclose!

title: Sonnet XCV
line: That tongue that tells the story of thy days,

title: Sonnet XCV
line: Making lascivious comments on thy sport,

title: Sonnet XCV
line: Cannot dispraise but in a kind of praise;

title: Sonnet XCV
line: Naming thy name blesses an ill report.

title: Sonnet XCV
line: O, what a mansion have those vices got

title: Sonnet XCV
line: Which for their habitation chose out thee,

title: Sonnet XCV
line: Where beauty's veil doth cover every blot,

title: Sonnet XCV
line: And all things turn to fair that eyes can see!

title: Sonnet XCV
line: Take heed, dear heart, of this large privilege;

title: Sonnet XCV
line: The hardest knife ill-used doth lose his edge.

title: Sonnet XCVI
line: Some say thy fault is youth, some wantonness;

title: Sonnet XCVI
line: Some say thy grace is youth and gentle sport;

title: Sonnet XCVI
line: Both grace and faults are loved of more and less;

title: Sonnet XCVI
line: Thou makest faults graces that to thee resort.

title: Sonnet XCVI
line: As on the finger of a throned queen

title: Sonnet XCVI
line: The basest jewel will be well esteem'd,

title: Sonnet XCVI
line: So are those errors that in thee are seen

title: Sonnet XCVI
line: To truths translated and for true things deem'd.

title: Sonnet XCVI
line: How many lambs might the stem wolf betray,

title: Sonnet XCVI
line: If like a lamb he could his looks translate!

title: Sonnet XCVI
line: How many gazers mightst thou lead away,

title: Sonnet XCVI
line: If thou wouldst use the strength of all thy state!

title: Sonnet XCVI
line: But do not so; I love thee in such sort

title: Sonnet XCVI
line: As, thou being mine, mine is thy good report.

title: Sonnet XCVII
line: How like a winter hath my absence been

title: Sonnet XCVII
line: From thee, the pleasure of the fleeting year!

title: Sonnet XCVII
line: What freezings have I felt, what dark days seen!

title: Sonnet XCVII
line: What old December's bareness every where!

title: Sonnet XCVII
line: And yet this time removed was summer's time,

title: Sonnet XCVII
line: The teeming autumn, big with rich increase,

title: Sonnet XCVII
line: Bearing the wanton burden of the prime,

title: Sonnet XCVII
line: Like widow'd wombs after their lords' decease:

title: Sonnet XCVII
line: Yet this abundant issue seem'd to me

title: Sonnet XCVII
line: But hope of orphans and unfather'd fruit;

title: Sonnet XCVII
line: For summer and his pleasures wait on thee,

title: Sonnet XCVII
line: And, thou away, the very birds are mute;

title: Sonnet XCVII
line: Or, if they sing, 'tis with so dull a cheer

title: Sonnet XCVII
line: That leaves look pale, dreading the winter's near.

title: Sonnet XCVIII
line: From you have I been absent in the spring,

title: Sonnet XCVIII
line: When proud-pied April dress'd in all his trim

title: Sonnet XCVIII
line: Hath put a spirit of youth in every thing,

title: Sonnet XCVIII
line: That heavy Saturn laugh'd and leap'd with him.

title: Sonnet XCVIII
line: Yet nor the lays of birds nor the sweet smell

title: Sonnet XCVIII
line: Of different flowers in odour and in hue

title: Sonnet XCVIII
line: Could make me any summer's story tell,

title: Sonnet XCVIII
line: Or from their proud lap pluck them where they grew;

title: Sonnet XCVIII
line: Nor did I wonder at the lily's white,

title: Sonnet XCVIII
line: Nor praise the deep vermilion in the rose;

title: Sonnet XCVIII
line: They were but sweet, but figures of delight,

title: Sonnet XCVIII
line: Drawn after you, you pattern of all those.

title: Sonnet XCVIII
line: Yet seem'd it winter still, and, you away,

title: Sonnet XCVIII
line: As with your shadow I with these did play:

title: Sonnet XCIX
line: The forward violet thus did I chide:

title: Sonnet XCIX
line: Sweet thief, whence didst thou steal thy sweet that smells,

title: Sonnet XCIX
line: If not from my love's breath? The purple pride

title: Sonnet XCIX
line: Which on thy soft cheek for complexion dwells

title: Sonnet XCIX
line: In my love's veins thou hast too grossly dyed.

title: Sonnet XCIX
line: The lily I condemned for thy hand,

title: Sonnet XCIX
line: And buds of marjoram had stol'n thy hair:

title: Sonnet XCIX
line: The roses fearfully on thorns did stand,

title: Sonnet XCIX
line: One blushing shame, another white despair;

title: Sonnet XCIX
line: A third, nor red nor white, had stol'n of both

title: Sonnet XCIX
line: And to his robbery had annex'd thy breath;

title: Sonnet XCIX
line: But, for his theft, in pride of all his growth

title: Sonnet XCIX
line: A vengeful canker eat him up to death.

title: Sonnet XCIX
line: More flowers I noted, yet I none could see

title: Sonnet XCIX
line: But sweet or colour it had stol'n from thee.

title: Sonnet C
line: Where art thou, Muse, that thou forget'st so long

title: Sonnet C
line: To speak of that which gives thee all thy might?

title: Sonnet C
line: Spend'st thou thy fury on some worthless song,

title: Sonnet C
line: Darkening thy power to lend base subjects light?

title: Sonnet C
line: Return, forgetful Muse, and straight redeem

title: Sonnet C
line: In gentle numbers time so idly spent;

title: Sonnet C
line: Sing to the ear that doth thy lays esteem

title: Sonnet C
line: And gives thy pen both skill and argument.

title: Sonnet C
line: Rise, resty Muse, my love's sweet face survey,

title: Sonnet C
line: If Time have any wrinkle graven there;

title: Sonnet C
line: If any, be a satire to decay,

title: Sonnet C
line: And make Time's spoils despised every where.

title: Sonnet C
line: Give my love fame faster than Time wastes life;

title: Sonnet C
line: So thou prevent'st his scythe and crooked knife.

title: Sonnet CI
line: O truant Muse, what shall be thy amends

title: Sonnet CI
line: For thy neglect of truth in beauty dyed?

title: Sonnet CI
line: Both truth and beauty on my love depends;

title: Sonnet CI
line: So dost thou too, and therein dignified.

title: Sonnet CI
line: Make answer, Muse: wilt thou not haply say

title: Sonnet CI
line: 'Truth needs no colour, with his colour fix'd;

title: Sonnet CI
line: Beauty no pencil, beauty's truth to lay;

title: Sonnet CI
line: But best is best, if never intermix'd?'

title: Sonnet CI
line: Because he needs no praise, wilt thou be dumb?

title: Sonnet CI
line: Excuse not silence so; for't lies in thee

title: Sonnet CI
line: To make him much outlive a gilded tomb,

title: Sonnet CI
line: And to be praised of ages yet to be.

title: Sonnet CI
line: Then do thy office, Muse; I teach thee how

title: Sonnet CI
line: To make him seem long hence as he shows now.

title: Sonnet CII
line: My love is strengthen'd, though more weak in seeming;

title: Sonnet CII
line: I love not less, though less the show appear:

title: Sonnet CII
line: That love is merchandized whose rich esteeming

title: Sonnet CII
line: The owner's tongue doth publish every where.

title: Sonnet CII
line: Our love was new and then but in the spring

title: Sonnet CII
line: When I was wont to greet it with my lays,

title: Sonnet CII
line: As Philomel in summer's front doth sing

title: Sonnet CII
line: And stops her pipe in growth of riper days:

title: Sonnet CII
line: Not that the summer is less pleasant now

title: Sonnet CII
line: Than when her mournful hymns did hush the night,

title: Sonnet CII
line: But that wild music burthens every bough

title: Sonnet CII
line: And sweets grown common lose their dear delight.

title: Sonnet CII
line: Therefore like her I sometime hold my tongue,

title: Sonnet CII
line: Because I would not dull you with my song.

title: Sonnet CIII
line: Alack, what poverty my Muse brings forth,

title: Sonnet CIII
line: That having such a scope to show her pride,

title: Sonnet CIII
line: The argument all bare is of more worth

title: Sonnet CIII
line: Than when it hath my added praise beside!

title: Sonnet CIII
line: O, blame me not, if I no more can write!

title: Sonnet CIII
line: Look in your glass, and there appears a face

title: Sonnet CIII
line: That over-goes my blunt invention quite,

title: Sonnet CIII
line: Dulling my lines and doing me disgrace.

title: Sonnet CIII
line: Were it not sinful then, striving to mend,

title: Sonnet CIII
line: To mar the subject that before was well?

title: Sonnet CIII
line: For to no other pass my verses tend

title: Sonnet CIII
line: Than of your graces and your gifts to tell;

title: Sonnet CIII
line: And more, much more, than in my verse can sit

title: Sonnet CIII
line: Your own glass shows you when you look in it.

title: Sonnet CIV
line: To me, fair friend, you never can be old,

title: Sonnet CIV
line: For as you were when first your eye I eyed,

title: Sonnet CIV
line: Such seems your beauty still. Three winters cold

title: Sonnet CIV
line: Have from the forests shook three summers' pride,

title: Sonnet CIV
line: Three beauteous springs to yellow autumn turn'd

title: Sonnet CIV
line: In process of the seasons have I seen,

title: Sonnet CIV
line: Three April perfumes in three hot Junes burn'd,

title: Sonnet CIV
line: Since first I saw you fresh, which yet are green.

title: Sonnet CIV
line: Ah! yet doth beauty, like a dial-hand,

title: Sonnet CIV
line: Steal from his figure and no pace perceived;

title: Sonnet CIV
line: So your sweet hue, which methinks still doth stand,

title: Sonnet CIV
line: Hath motion and mine eye may be deceived:

title: Sonnet CIV
line: For fear of which, hear this, thou age unbred;

title: Sonnet CIV
line: Ere you were born was beauty's summer dead.

title: Sonnet CV
line: Let not my love be call'd idolatry,

title: Sonnet CV
line: Nor my beloved as an idol show,

title: Sonnet CV
line: Since all alike my songs and praises be

title: Sonnet CV
line: To one, of one, still such, and ever so.

title: Sonnet CV
line: Kind is my love to-day, to-morrow kind,

title: Sonnet CV
line: Still constant in a wondrous excellence;

title: Sonnet CV
line: Therefore my verse to constancy confined,

title: Sonnet CV
line: One thing expressing, leaves out difference.

title: Sonnet CV
line: 'Fair, kind and true' is all my argument,

title: Sonnet CV
line: 'Fair, kind, and true' varying to other words;

title: Sonnet CV
line: And in this change is my invention spent,

title: Sonnet CV
line: Three themes in one, which wondrous scope affords.

title: Sonnet CV
line: 'Fair, kind, and true,' have often lived alone,

title: Sonnet CV
line: Which three till now never kept seat in one.

title: Sonnet CVI
line: When in the chronicle of wasted time

title: Sonnet CVI
line: I see descriptions of the fairest wights,

title: Sonnet CVI
line: And beauty making beautiful old rhyme

title: Sonnet CVI
line: In praise of ladies dead and lovely knights,

title: Sonnet CVI
line: Then, in the blazon of sweet beauty's best,

title: Sonnet CVI
line: Of hand, of foot, of lip, of eye, of brow,

title: Sonnet CVI
line: I see their antique pen would have express'd

title: Sonnet CVI
line: Even such a beauty as you master now.

title: Sonnet CVI
line: So all their praises are but prophecies

title: Sonnet CVI
line: Of this our time, all you prefiguring;

title: Sonnet CVI
line: And, for they look'd but with divining eyes,

title: Sonnet CVI
line: They had not skill enough your worth to sing:

title: Sonnet CVI
line: For we, which now behold these present days,

title: Sonnet CVI
line: Had eyes to wonder, but lack tongues to praise.

title: Sonnet CVII
line: Not mine own fears, nor the prophetic soul

title: Sonnet CVII
line: Of the wide world dreaming on things to come,

title: Sonnet CVII
line: Can yet the lease of my true love control,

title: Sonnet CVII
line: Supposed as forfeit to a confined doom.

title: Sonnet CVII
line: The mortal moon hath her eclipse endured

title: Sonnet CVII
line: And the sad augurs mock their own presage;

title: Sonnet CVII
line: Incertainties now crown themselves assured

title: Sonnet CVII
line: And peace proclaims olives of endless age.

title: Sonnet CVII
line: Now with the drops of this most balmy time

title: Sonnet CVII
line: My love looks fresh, and death to me subscribes,

title: Sonnet CVII
line: Since, spite of him, I'll live in this poor rhyme,

title: Sonnet CVII
line: While he insults o'er dull and speechless tribes:

title: Sonnet CVII
line: And thou in this shalt find thy monument,

title: Sonnet CVII
line: When tyrants' crests and tombs of brass are spent.

title: Sonnet CVIII
line: What's in the brain that ink may character

title: Sonnet CVIII
line: Which hath not figured to thee my true spirit?

title: Sonnet CVIII
line: What's new to speak, what new to register,

title: Sonnet CVIII
line: That may express my love or thy dear merit?

title: Sonnet CVIII
line: Nothing, sweet boy; but yet, like prayers divine,

title: Sonnet CVIII
line: I must, each day say o'er the very same,

title: Sonnet CVIII
line: Counting no old thing old, thou mine, I thine,

title: Sonnet CVIII
line: Even as when first I hallow'd thy fair name.

title: Sonnet CVIII
line: So that eternal love in love's fresh case

title: Sonnet CVIII
line: Weighs not the dust and injury of age,

title: Sonnet CVIII
line: Nor gives to necessary wrinkles place,

title: Sonnet CVIII
line: But makes antiquity for aye his page,

title: Sonnet CVIII
line: Finding the first conceit of love there bred

title: Sonnet CVIII
line: Where time and outward form would show it dead.

title: Sonnet CIX
line: O, never say that I was false of heart,

title: Sonnet CIX
line: Though absence seem'd my flame to qualify.

title: Sonnet CIX
line: As easy might I from myself depart

title: Sonnet CIX
line: As from my soul, which in thy breast doth lie:

title: Sonnet CIX
line: That is my home of love: if I have ranged,

title: Sonnet CIX
line: Like him that travels I return again,

title: Sonnet CIX
line: Just to the time, not with the time exchanged,

title: Sonnet CIX
line: So that myself bring water for my stain.

title: Sonnet CIX
line: Never believe, though in my nature reign'd

title: Sonnet CIX
line: All frailties that besiege all kinds of blood,

title: Sonnet CIX
line: That it could so preposterously be stain'd,

title: Sonnet CIX
line: To leave for nothing all thy sum of good;

title: Sonnet CIX
line: For nothing this wide universe I call,

title: Sonnet CIX
line: Save thou, my rose; in it thou art my all.

title: Sonnet CX
line: Alas, 'tis true I have gone here and there

title: Sonnet CX
line: And made myself a motley to the view,

title: Sonnet CX
line: Gored mine own thoughts, sold cheap what is most dear,

title: Sonnet CX
line: Made old offences of affections new;

title: Sonnet CX
line: Most true it is that I have look'd on truth

title: Sonnet CX
line: Askance and strangely: but, by all above,

title: Sonnet CX
line: These blenches gave my heart another youth,

title: Sonnet CX
line: And worse essays proved thee my best of love.

title: Sonnet CX
line: Now all is done, have what shall have no end:

title: Sonnet CX
line: Mine appetite I never more will grind

title: Sonnet CX
line: On newer proof, to try an older friend,

title: Sonnet CX
line: A god in love, to whom I am confined.

title: Sonnet CX
line: Then give me welcome, next my heaven the best,

title: Sonnet CX
line: Even to thy pure and most most loving breast.

title: Sonnet CXI
line: O, for my sake do you with Fortune chide,

title: Sonnet CXI
line: The guilty goddess of my harmful deeds,

title: Sonnet CXI
line: That did not better for my life provide

title: Sonnet CXI
line: Than public means which public manners breeds.

title: Sonnet CXI
line: Thence comes it that my name receives a brand,

title: Sonnet CXI
line: And almost thence my nature is subdued

title: Sonnet CXI
line: To what it works in, like the dyer's hand:

title: Sonnet CXI
line: Pity me then and wish I were renew'd;

title: Sonnet CXI
line: Whilst, like a willing patient, I will drink

title: Sonnet CXI
line: Potions of eisel 'gainst my strong infection

title: Sonnet CXI
line: No bitterness that I will bitter think,

title: Sonnet CXI
line: Nor double penance, to correct correction.

title: Sonnet CXI
line: Pity me then, dear friend, and I assure ye

title: Sonnet CXI
line: Even that your pity is enough to cure me.

title: Sonnet CXII
line: Your love and pity doth the impression fill

title: Sonnet CXII
line: Which vulgar scandal stamp'd upon my brow;

title: Sonnet CXII
line: For what care I who calls me well or ill,

title: Sonnet CXII
line: So you o'er-green my bad, my good allow?

title: Sonnet CXII
line: You are my all the world, and I must strive

title: Sonnet CXII
line: To know my shames and praises from your tongue:

title: Sonnet CXII
line: None else to me, nor I to none alive,

title: Sonnet CXII
line: That my steel'd sense or changes right or wrong.

title: Sonnet CXII
line: In so profound abysm I throw all care

title: Sonnet CXII
line: Of others' voices, that my adder's sense

title: Sonnet CXII
line: To critic and to flatterer stopped are.

title: Sonnet CXII
line: Mark how with my neglect I do dispense:

title: Sonnet CXII
line: You are so strongly in my purpose bred

title: Sonnet CXII
line: That all the world besides methinks are dead.

title: Sonnet CXIII
line: Since I left you, mine eye is in my mind;

title: Sonnet CXIII
line: And that which governs me to go about

title: Sonnet CXIII
line: Doth part his function and is partly blind,

title: Sonnet CXIII
line: Seems seeing, but effectually is out;

title: Sonnet CXIII
line: For it no form delivers to the heart

title: Sonnet CXIII
line: Of bird of flower, or shape, which it doth latch:

title: Sonnet CXIII
line: Of his quick objects hath the mind no part,

title: Sonnet CXIII
line: Nor his own vision holds what it doth catch:

title: Sonnet CXIII
line: For if it see the rudest or gentlest sight,

title: Sonnet CXIII
line: The most sweet favour or deformed'st creature,

title: Sonnet CXIII
line: The mountain or the sea, the day or night,

title: Sonnet CXIII
line: The crow or dove, it shapes them to your feature:

title: Sonnet CXIII
line: Incapable of more, replete with you,

title: Sonnet CXIII
line: My most true mind thus makes mine eye untrue.

title: Sonnet CXIV
line: Or whether doth my mind, being crown'd with you,

title: Sonnet CXIV
line: Drink up the monarch's plague, this flattery?

title: Sonnet CXIV
line: Or whether shall I say, mine eye saith true,

title: Sonnet CXIV
line: And that your love taught it this alchemy,

title: Sonnet CXIV
line: To make of monsters and things indigest

title: Sonnet CXIV
line: Such cherubins as your sweet self resemble,

title: Sonnet CXIV
line: Creating every bad a perfect best,

title: Sonnet CXIV
line: As fast as objects to his beams assemble?

title: Sonnet CXIV
line: O,'tis the first; 'tis flattery in my seeing,

title: Sonnet CXIV
line: And my great mind most kingly drinks it up:

title: Sonnet CXIV
line: Mine eye well knows what with his gust is 'greeing,

title: Sonnet CXIV
line: And to his palate doth prepare the cup:

title: Sonnet CXIV
line: If it be poison'd, 'tis the lesser sin

title: Sonnet CXIV
line: That mine eye loves it and doth first begin.

title: Sonnet CXV
line: Those lines that I before have writ do lie,

title: Sonnet CXV
line: Even those that said I could not love you dearer:

title: Sonnet CXV
line: Yet then my judgment knew no reason why

title: Sonnet CXV
line: My most full flame should afterwards burn clearer.

title: Sonnet CXV
line: But reckoning time, whose million'd accidents

title: Sonnet CXV
line: Creep in 'twixt vows and change decrees of kings,

title: Sonnet CXV
line: Tan sacred beauty, blunt the sharp'st intents,

title: Sonnet CXV
line: Divert strong minds to the course of altering things;

title: Sonnet CXV
line: Alas, why, fearing of time's tyranny,

title: Sonnet CXV
line: Might I not then say 'Now I love you best,'

title: Sonnet CXV
line: When I was certain o'er incertainty,

title: Sonnet CXV
line: Crowning the present, doubting of the rest?

title: Sonnet CXV
line: Love is a babe; then might I not say so,

title: Sonnet CXV
line: To give full growth to that which still doth grow?

title: Sonnet CXVI
line: Let me not to the marriage of true minds

title: Sonnet CXVI
line: Admit impediments. Love is not love

title: Sonnet CXVI
line: Which alters when it alteration finds,

title: Sonnet CXVI
line: Or bends with the remover to remove:

title: Sonnet CXVI
line: O no! it is an ever-fixed mark

title: Sonnet CXVI
line: That looks on tempests and is never shaken;

title: Sonnet CXVI
line: It is the star to every wandering bark,

title: Sonnet CXVI
line: Whose worth's unknown, although his height be taken.

title: Sonnet CXVI
line: Love's not Time's fool, though rosy lips and cheeks

title: Sonnet CXVI
line: Within his bending sickle's compass come:

title: Sonnet CXVI
line: Love alters not with his brief hours and weeks,

title: Sonnet CXVI
line: But bears it out even to the edge of doom.

title: Sonnet CXVI
line: If this be error and upon me proved,

title: Sonnet CXVI
line: I never writ, nor no man ever loved.

title: Sonnet CXVII
line: Accuse me thus: that I have scanted all

title: Sonnet CXVII
line: Wherein I should your great deserts repay,

title: Sonnet CXVII
line: Forgot upon your dearest love to call,

title: Sonnet CXVII
line: Whereto all bonds do tie me day by day;

title: Sonnet CXVII
line: That I have frequent been with unknown minds

title: Sonnet CXVII
line: And given to time your own dear-purchased right

title: Sonnet CXVII
line: That I have hoisted sail to all the winds

title: Sonnet CXVII
line: Which should transport me farthest from your sight.

title: Sonnet CXVII
line: Book both my wilfulness and errors down

title: Sonnet CXVII
line: And on just proof surmise accumulate;

title: Sonnet CXVII
line: Bring me within the level of your frown,

title: Sonnet CXVII
line: But shoot not at me in your waken'd hate;

title: Sonnet CXVII
line: Since my appeal says I did strive to prove

title: Sonnet CXVII
line: The constancy and virtue of your love.

title: Sonnet CXVIII
line: Like as, to make our appetites more keen,

title: Sonnet CXVIII
line: With eager compounds we our palate urge,

title: Sonnet CXVIII
line: As, to prevent our maladies unseen,

title: Sonnet CXVIII
line: We sicken to shun sickness when we purge,

title: Sonnet CXVIII
line: Even so, being tuff of your ne'er-cloying sweetness,

title: Sonnet CXVIII
line: To bitter sauces did I frame my feeding

title: Sonnet CXVIII
line: And, sick of welfare, found a kind of meetness

title: Sonnet CXVIII
line: To be diseased ere that there was true needing.

title: Sonnet CXVIII
line: Thus policy in love, to anticipate

title: Sonnet CXVIII
line: The ills that were not, grew to faults assured

title: Sonnet CXVIII
line: And brought to medicine a healthful state

title: Sonnet CXVIII
line: Which, rank of goodness, would by ill be cured:

title: Sonnet CXVIII
line: But thence I learn, and find the lesson true,

title: Sonnet CXVIII
line: Drugs poison him that so fell sick of you.

title: Sonnet CXIX
line: What potions have I drunk of Siren tears,

title: Sonnet CXIX
line: Distill'd from limbecks foul as hell within,

title: Sonnet CXIX
line: Applying fears to hopes and hopes to fears,

title: Sonnet CXIX
line: Still losing when I saw myself to win!

title: Sonnet CXIX
line: What wretched errors hath my heart committed,

title: Sonnet CXIX
line: Whilst it hath thought itself so blessed never!

title: Sonnet CXIX
line: How have mine eyes out of their spheres been fitted

title: Sonnet CXIX
line: In the distraction of this madding fever!

title: Sonnet CXIX
line: O benefit of ill! now I find true

title: Sonnet CXIX
line: That better is by evil still made better;

title: Sonnet CXIX
line: And ruin'd love, when it is built anew,

title: Sonnet CXIX
line: Grows fairer than at first, more strong, far greater.

title: Sonnet CXIX
line: So I return rebuked to my content

title: Sonnet CXIX
line: And gain by ill thrice more than I have spent.

title: Sonnet CXX
line: That you were once unkind befriends me now,

title: Sonnet CXX
line: And for that sorrow which I then did feel

title: Sonnet CXX
line: Needs must I under my transgression bow,

title: Sonnet CXX
line: Unless my nerves were brass or hammer'd steel.

title: Sonnet CXX
line: For if you were by my unkindness shaken

title: Sonnet CXX
line: As I by yours, you've pass'd a hell of time,

title: Sonnet CXX
line: And I, a tyrant, have no leisure taken

title: Sonnet CXX
line: To weigh how once I suffered in your crime.

title: Sonnet CXX
line: O, that our night of woe might have remember'd

title: Sonnet CXX
line: My deepest sense, how hard true sorrow hits,

title: Sonnet CXX
line: And soon to you, as you to me, then tender'd

title: Sonnet CXX
line: The humble slave which wounded bosoms fits!

title: Sonnet CXX
line: But that your trespass now becomes a fee;

title: Sonnet CXX
line: Mine ransoms yours, and yours must ransom me.

title: Sonnet CXXI
line: 'Tis better to be vile than vile esteem'd,

title: Sonnet CXXI
line: When not to be receives reproach of being,

title: Sonnet CXXI
line: And the just pleasure lost which is so deem'd

title: Sonnet CXXI
line: Not by our feeling but by others' seeing:

title: Sonnet CXXI
line: For why should others false adulterate eyes

title: Sonnet CXXI
line: Give salutation to my sportive blood?

title: Sonnet CXXI
line: Or on my frailties why are frailer spies,

title: Sonnet CXXI
line: Which in their wills count bad what I think good?

title: Sonnet CXXI
line: No, I am that I am, and they that level

title: Sonnet CXXI
line: At my abuses reckon up their own:

title: Sonnet CXXI
line: I may be straight, though they themselves be bevel;

title: Sonnet CXXI
line: By their rank thoughts my deeds must not be shown;

title: Sonnet CXXI
line: Unless this general evil they maintain,

title: Sonnet CXXI
line: All men are bad, and in their badness reign.

title: Sonnet CXXII
line: Thy gift, thy tables, are within my brain

title: Sonnet CXXII
line: Full character'd with lasting memory,

title: Sonnet CXXII
line: Which shall above that idle rank remain

title: Sonnet CXXII
line: Beyond all date, even to eternity;

title: Sonnet CXXII
line: Or at the least, so long as brain and heart

title: Sonnet CXXII
line: Have faculty by nature to subsist;

title: Sonnet CXXII
line: Till each to razed oblivion yield his part

title: Sonnet CXXII
line: Of thee, thy record never can be miss'd.

title: Sonnet CXXII
line: That poor retention could not so much hold,

title: Sonnet CXXII
line: Nor need I tallies thy dear love to score;

title: Sonnet CXXII
line: Therefore to give them from me was I bold,

title: Sonnet CXXII
line: To trust those tables that receive thee more:

title: Sonnet CXXII
line: To keep an adjunct to remember thee

title: Sonnet CXXII
line: Were to import forgetfulness in me.

title: Sonnet CXXIII
line: No, Time, thou shalt not boast that I do change:

title: Sonnet CXXIII
line: Thy pyramids built up with newer might

title: Sonnet CXXIII
line: To me are nothing novel, nothing strange;

title: Sonnet CXXIII
line: They are but dressings of a former sight.

title: Sonnet CXXIII
line: Our dates are brief, and therefore we admire

title: Sonnet CXXIII
line: What thou dost foist upon us that is old,

title: Sonnet CXXIII
line: And rather make them born to our desire

title: Sonnet CXXIII
line: Than think that we before have heard them told.

title: Sonnet CXXIII
line: Thy registers and thee I both defy,

title: Sonnet CXXIII
line: Not wondering at the present nor the past,

title: Sonnet CXXIII
line: For thy records and what we see doth lie,

title: Sonnet CXXIII
line: Made more or less by thy continual haste.

title: Sonnet CXXIII
line: This I do vow and this shall ever be;

title: Sonnet CXXIII
line: I will be true, despite thy scythe and thee.

title: Sonnet CXXIV
line: If my dear love were but the child of state,

title: Sonnet CXXIV
line: It might for Fortune's bastard be unfather'd'

title: Sonnet CXXIV
line: As subject to Time's love or to Time's hate,

title: Sonnet CXXIV
line: Weeds among weeds, or flowers with flowers gather'd.

title: Sonnet CXXIV
line: No, it was builded far from accident;

title: Sonnet CXXIV
line: It suffers not in smiling pomp, nor falls

title: Sonnet CXXIV
line: Under the blow of thralled discontent,

title: Sonnet CXXIV
line: Whereto the inviting time our fashion calls:

title: Sonnet CXXIV
line: It fears not policy, that heretic,

title: Sonnet CXXIV
line: Which works on leases of short-number'd hours,

title: Sonnet CXXIV
line: But all alone stands hugely politic,

title: Sonnet CXXIV
line: That it nor grows with heat nor drowns with showers.

title: Sonnet CXXIV
line: To this I witness call the fools of time,

title: Sonnet CXXIV
line: Which die for goodness, who have lived for crime.

title: Sonnet CXXV
line: Were 't aught to me I bore the canopy,

title: Sonnet CXXV
line: With my extern the outward honouring,

title: Sonnet CXXV
line: Or laid great bases for eternity,

title: Sonnet CXXV
line: Which prove more short than waste or ruining?

title: Sonnet CXXV
line: Have I not seen dwellers on form and favour

title: Sonnet CXXV
line: Lose all, and more, by paying too much rent,

title: Sonnet CXXV
line: For compound sweet forgoing simple savour,

title: Sonnet CXXV
line: Pitiful thrivers, in their gazing spent?

title: Sonnet CXXV
line: No, let me be obsequious in thy heart,

title: Sonnet CXXV
line: And take thou my oblation, poor but free,

title: Sonnet CXXV
line: Which is not mix'd with seconds, knows no art,

title: Sonnet CXXV
line: But mutual render, only me for thee.

title: Sonnet CXXV
line: Hence, thou suborn'd informer! a true soul

title: Sonnet CXXV
line: When most impeach'd stands least in thy control.

title: Sonnet CXXVI
line: O thou, my lovely boy, who in thy power

title: Sonnet CXXVI
line: Dost hold Time's fickle glass, his sickle, hour;

title: Sonnet CXXVI
line: Who hast by waning grown, and therein show'st

title: Sonnet CXXVI
line: Thy lovers withering as thy sweet self grow'st;

title: Sonnet CXXVI
line: If Nature, sovereign mistress over wrack,

title: Sonnet CXXVI
line: As thou goest onwards, still will pluck thee back,

title: Sonnet CXXVI
line: She keeps thee to this purpose, that her skill

title: Sonnet CXXVI
line: May time disgrace and wretched minutes kill.

title: Sonnet CXXVI
line: Yet fear her, O thou minion of her pleasure!

title: Sonnet CXXVI
line: She may detain, but not still keep, her treasure:

title: Sonnet CXXVI
line: Her audit, though delay'd, answer'd must be,

title: Sonnet CXXVI
line: And her quietus is to render thee.

title: Sonnet CXXVII
line: In the old age black was not counted fair,

title: Sonnet CXXVII
line: Or if it were, it bore not beauty's name;

title: Sonnet CXXVII
line: But now is black beauty's successive heir,

title: Sonnet CXXVII
line: And beauty slander'd with a bastard shame:

title: Sonnet CXXVII
line: For since each hand hath put on nature's power,

title: Sonnet CXXVII
line: Fairing the foul with art's false borrow'd face,

title: Sonnet CXXVII
line: Sweet beauty hath no name, no holy bower,

title: Sonnet CXXVII
line: But is profaned, if not lives in disgrace.

title: Sonnet CXXVII
line: Therefore my mistress' brows are raven black,

title: Sonnet CXXVII
line: Her eyes so suited, and they mourners seem

title: Sonnet CXXVII
line: At such who, not born fair, no beauty lack,

title: Sonnet CXXVII
line: Slandering creation with a false esteem:

title: Sonnet CXXVII
line: Yet so they mourn, becoming of their woe,

title: Sonnet CXXVII
line: That every tongue says beauty should look so.

title: Sonnet CXXVIII
line: How oft, when thou, my music, music play'st,

title: Sonnet CXXVIII
line: Upon that blessed wood whose motion sounds

title: Sonnet CXXVIII
line: With thy sweet fingers, when thou gently sway'st

title: Sonnet CXXVIII
line: The wiry concord that mine ear confounds,

title: Sonnet CXXVIII
line: Do I envy those jacks that nimble leap

title: Sonnet CXXVIII
line: To kiss the tender inward of thy hand,

title: Sonnet CXXVIII
line: Whilst my poor lips, which should that harvest reap,

title: Sonnet CXXVIII
line: At the wood's boldness by thee blushing stand!

title: Sonnet CXXVIII
line: To be so tickled, they would change their state

title: Sonnet CXXVIII
line: And situation with those dancing chips,

title: Sonnet CXXVIII
line: O'er whom thy fingers walk with gentle gait,

title: Sonnet CXXVIII
line: Making dead wood more blest than living lips.

title: Sonnet CXXVIII
line: Since saucy jacks so happy are in this,

title: Sonnet CXXVIII
line: Give them thy fingers, me thy lips to kiss.

title: Sonnet CXXIX
line: The expense of spirit in a waste of shame

title: Sonnet CXXIX
line: Is lust in action; and till action, lust

title: Sonnet CXXIX
line: Is perjured, murderous, bloody, full of blame,

title: Sonnet CXXIX
line: Savage, extreme, rude, cruel, not to trust,

title: Sonnet CXXIX
line: Enjoy'd no sooner but despised straight,

title: Sonnet CXXIX
line: Past reason hunted, and no sooner had

title: Sonnet CXXIX
line: Past reason hated, as a swallow'd bait

title: Sonnet CXXIX
line: On purpose laid to make the taker mad;

title: Sonnet CXXIX
line: Mad in pursuit and in possession so;

title: Sonnet CXXIX
line: Had, having, and in quest to have, extreme;

title: Sonnet CXXIX
line: A bliss in proof, and proved, a very woe;

title: Sonnet CXXIX
line: Before, a joy proposed; behind, a dream.

title: Sonnet CXXIX
line: All this the world well knows; yet none knows well

title: Sonnet CXXIX
line: To shun the heaven that leads men to this hell.

title: Sonnet CXXX
line: My mistress' eyes are nothing like the sun;

title: Sonnet CXXX
line: Coral is far more red than her lips' red;

title: Sonnet CXXX
line: If snow be white, why then her breasts are dun;

title: Sonnet CXXX
line: If hairs be wires, black wires grow on her head.

title: Sonnet CXXX
line: I have seen roses damask'd, red and white,

title: Sonnet CXXX
line: But no such roses see I in her cheeks;

title: Sonnet CXXX
line: And in some perfumes is there more delight

title: Sonnet CXXX
line: Than in the breath that from my mistress reeks.

title: Sonnet CXXX
line: I love to hear her speak, yet well I know

title: Sonnet CXXX
line: That music hath a far more pleasing sound;

title: Sonnet CXXX
line: I grant I never saw a goddess go;

title: Sonnet CXXX
line: My mistress, when she walks, treads on the ground:

title: Sonnet CXXX
line: And yet, by heaven, I think my love as rare

title: Sonnet CXXX
line: As any she belied with false compare.

title: Sonnet CXXXI
line: Thou art as tyrannous, so as thou art,

title: Sonnet CXXXI
line: As those whose beauties proudly make them cruel;

title: Sonnet CXXXI
line: For well thou know'st to my dear doting heart

title: Sonnet CXXXI
line: Thou art the fairest and most precious jewel.

title: Sonnet CXXXI
line: Yet, in good faith, some say that thee behold

title: Sonnet CXXXI
line: Thy face hath not the power to make love groan:

title: Sonnet CXXXI
line: To say they err I dare not be so bold,

title: Sonnet CXXXI
line: Although I swear it to myself alone.

title: Sonnet CXXXI
line: And, to be sure that is not false I swear,

title: Sonnet CXXXI
line: A thousand groans, but thinking on thy face,

title: Sonnet CXXXI
line: One on another's neck, do witness bear

title: Sonnet CXXXI
line: Thy black is fairest in my judgment's place.

title: Sonnet CXXXI
line: In nothing art thou black save in thy deeds,

title: Sonnet CXXXI
line: And thence this slander, as I think, proceeds.

title: Sonnet CXXXII
line: Thine eyes I love, and they, as pitying me,

title: Sonnet CXXXII
line: Knowing thy heart torments me with disdain,

title: Sonnet CXXXII
line: Have put on black and loving mourners be,

title: Sonnet CXXXII
line: Looking with pretty ruth upon my pain.

title: Sonnet CXXXII
line: And truly not the morning sun of heaven

title: Sonnet CXXXII
line: Better becomes the grey cheeks of the east,

title: Sonnet CXXXII
line: Nor that full star that ushers in the even

title: Sonnet CXXXII
line: Doth half that glory to the sober west,

title: Sonnet CXXXII
line: As those two mourning eyes become thy face:

title: Sonnet CXXXII
line: O, let it then as well beseem thy heart

title: Sonnet CXXXII
line: To mourn for me, since mourning doth thee grace,

title: Sonnet CXXXII
line: And suit thy pity like in every part.

title: Sonnet CXXXII
line: Then will I swear beauty herself is black

title: Sonnet CXXXII
line: And all they foul that thy complexion lack.

title: Sonnet CXXXIII
line: Beshrew that heart that makes my heart to groan

title: Sonnet CXXXIII
line: For that deep wound it gives my friend and me!

title: Sonnet CXXXIII
line: Is't not enough to torture me alone,

title: Sonnet CXXXIII
line: But slave to slavery my sweet'st friend must be?

title: Sonnet CXXXIII
line: Me from myself thy cruel eye hath taken,

title: Sonnet CXXXIII
line: And my next self thou harder hast engross'd:

title: Sonnet CXXXIII
line: Of him, myself, and thee, I am forsaken;

title: Sonnet CXXXIII
line: A torment thrice threefold thus to be cross'd.

title: Sonnet CXXXIII
line: Prison my heart in thy steel bosom's ward,

title: Sonnet CXXXIII
line: But then my friend's heart let my poor heart bail;

title: Sonnet CXXXIII
line: Whoe'er keeps me, let my heart be his guard;

title: Sonnet CXXXIII
line: Thou canst not then use rigor in my gaol:

title: Sonnet CXXXIII
line: And yet thou wilt; for I, being pent in thee,

title: Sonnet CXXXIII
line: Perforce am thine, and all that is in me.

title: Sonnet CXXXIV
line: So, now I have confess'd that he is thine,

title: Sonnet CXXXIV
line: And I myself am mortgaged to thy will,

title: Sonnet CXXXIV
line: Myself I'll forfeit, so that other mine

title: Sonnet CXXXIV
line: Thou wilt restore, to be my comfort still:

title: Sonnet CXXXIV
line: But thou wilt not, nor he will not be free,

title: Sonnet CXXXIV
line: For thou art covetous and he is kind;

title: Sonnet CXXXIV
line: He learn'd but surety-like to write for me

title: Sonnet CXXXIV
line: Under that bond that him as fast doth bind.

title: Sonnet CXXXIV
line: The statute of thy beauty thou wilt take,

title: Sonnet CXXXIV
line: Thou usurer, that put'st forth all to use,

title: Sonnet CXXXIV
line: And sue a friend came debtor for my sake;

title: Sonnet CXXXIV
line: So him I lose through my unkind abuse.

title: Sonnet CXXXIV
line: Him have I lost; thou hast both him and me:

title: Sonnet CXXXIV
line: He pays the whole, and yet am I not free.

title: Sonnet CXXXV
line: Whoever hath her wish, thou hast thy 'Will,'

title: Sonnet CXXXV
line: And 'Will' to boot, and 'Will' in overplus;

title: Sonnet CXXXV
line: More than enough am I that vex thee still,

title: Sonnet CXXXV
line: To thy sweet will making addition thus.

title: Sonnet CXXXV
line: Wilt thou, whose will is large and spacious,

title: Sonnet CXXXV
line: Not once vouchsafe to hide my will in thine?

title: Sonnet CXXXV
line: Shall will in others seem right gracious,

title: Sonnet CXXXV
line: And in my will no fair acceptance shine?

title: Sonnet CXXXV
line: The sea all water, yet receives rain still

title: Sonnet CXXXV
line: And in abundance addeth to his store;

title: Sonnet CXXXV
line: So thou, being rich in 'Will,' add to thy 'Will'

title: Sonnet CXXXV
line: One will of mine, to make thy large 'Will' more.

title: Sonnet CXXXV
line: Let no unkind, no fair beseechers kill;

title: Sonnet CXXXV
line: Think all but one, and me in that one 'Will.'

title: Sonnet CXXXVI
line: If thy soul cheque thee that I come so near,

title: Sonnet CXXXVI
line: Swear to thy blind soul that I was thy 'Will,'

title: Sonnet CXXXVI
line: And will, thy soul knows, is admitted there;

title: Sonnet CXXXVI
line: Thus far for love my love-suit, sweet, fulfil.

title: Sonnet CXXXVI
line: 'Will' will fulfil the treasure of thy love,

title: Sonnet CXXXVI
line: Ay, fill it full with wills, and my will one.

title: Sonnet CXXXVI
line: In things of great receipt with ease we prove

title: Sonnet CXXXVI
line: Among a number one is reckon'd none:

title: Sonnet CXXXVI
line: Then in the number let me pass untold,

title: Sonnet CXXXVI
line: Though in thy stores' account I one must be;

title: Sonnet CXXXVI
line: For nothing hold me, so it please thee hold

title: Sonnet CXXXVI
line: That nothing me, a something sweet to thee:

title: Sonnet CXXXVI
line: Make but my name thy love, and love that still,

title: Sonnet CXXXVI
line: And then thou lovest me, for my name is 'Will.'

title: Sonnet CXXXVII
line: Thou blind fool, Love, what dost thou to mine eyes,

title: Sonnet CXXXVII
line: That they behold, and see not what they see?

title: Sonnet CXXXVII
line: They know what beauty is, see where it lies,

title: Sonnet CXXXVII
line: Yet what the best is take the worst to be.

title: Sonnet CXXXVII
line: If eyes corrupt by over-partial looks

title: Sonnet CXXXVII
line: Be anchor'd in the bay where all men ride,

title: Sonnet CXXXVII
line: Why of eyes' falsehood hast thou forged hooks,

title: Sonnet CXXXVII
line: Whereto the judgment of my heart is tied?

title: Sonnet CXXXVII
line: Why should my heart think that a several plot

title: Sonnet CXXXVII
line: Which my heart knows the wide world's common place?

title: Sonnet CXXXVII
line: Or mine eyes seeing this, say this is not,

title: Sonnet CXXXVII
line: To put fair truth upon so foul a face?

title: Sonnet CXXXVII
line: In things right true my heart and eyes have erred,

title: Sonnet CXXXVII
line: And to this false plague are they now transferr'd.

title: Sonnet CXXXVIII
line: When my love swears that she is made of truth

title: Sonnet CXXXVIII
line: I do believe her, though I know she lies,

title: Sonnet CXXXVIII
line: That she might think me some untutor'd youth,

title: Sonnet CXXXVIII
line: Unlearned in the world's false subtleties.

title: Sonnet CXXXVIII
line: Thus vainly thinking that she thinks me young,

title: Sonnet CXXXVIII
line: Although she knows my days are past the best,

title: Sonnet CXXXVIII
line: Simply I credit her false speaking tongue:

title: Sonnet CXXXVIII
line: On both sides thus is simple truth suppress'd.

title: Sonnet CXXXVIII
line: But wherefore says she not she is unjust?

title: Sonnet CXXXVIII
line: And wherefore say not I that I am old?

title: Sonnet CXXXVIII
line: O, love's best habit is in seeming trust,

title: Sonnet CXXXVIII
line: And age in love loves not to have years told:

title: Sonnet CXXXVIII
line: Therefore I lie with her and she with me,

title: Sonnet CXXXVIII
line: And in our faults by lies we flatter'd be.

title: Sonnet CXXXIX
line: O, call not me to justify the wrong

title: Sonnet CXXXIX
line: That thy unkindness lays upon my heart;

title: Sonnet CXXXIX
line: Wound me not with thine eye but with thy tongue;

title: Sonnet CXXXIX
line: Use power with power and slay me not by art.

title: Sonnet CXXXIX
line: Tell me thou lovest elsewhere, but in my sight,

title: Sonnet CXXXIX
line: Dear heart, forbear to glance thine eye aside:

title: Sonnet CXXXIX
line: What need'st thou wound with cunning when thy might

title: Sonnet CXXXIX
line: Is more than my o'er-press'd defense can bide?

title: Sonnet CXXXIX
line: Let me excuse thee: ah! my love well knows

title: Sonnet CXXXIX
line: Her pretty looks have been mine enemies,

title: Sonnet CXXXIX
line: And therefore from my face she turns my foes,

title: Sonnet CXXXIX
line: That they elsewhere might dart their injuries:

title: Sonnet CXXXIX
line: Yet do not so; but since I am near slain,

title: Sonnet CXXXIX
line: Kill me outright with looks and rid my pain.

title: Sonnet CXL
line: Be wise as thou art cruel; do not press

title: Sonnet CXL
line: My tongue-tied patience with too much disdain;

title: Sonnet CXL
line: Lest sorrow lend me words and words express

title: Sonnet CXL
line: The manner of my pity-wanting pain.

title: Sonnet CXL
line: If I might teach thee wit, better it were,

title: Sonnet CXL
line: Though not to love, yet, love, to tell me so;

title: Sonnet CXL
line: As testy sick men, when their deaths be near,

title: Sonnet CXL
line: No news but health from their physicians know;

title: Sonnet CXL
line: For if I should despair, I should grow mad,

title: Sonnet CXL
line: And in my madness might speak ill of thee:

title: Sonnet CXL
line: Now this ill-wresting world is grown so bad,

title: Sonnet CXL
line: Mad slanderers by mad ears believed be,

title: Sonnet CXL
line: That I may not be so, nor thou belied,

title: Sonnet CXL
line: Bear thine eyes straight, though thy proud heart go wide.

title: Sonnet CXLI
line: In faith, I do not love thee with mine eyes,

title: Sonnet CXLI
line: For they in thee a thousand errors note;

title: Sonnet CXLI
line: But 'tis my heart that loves what they despise,

title: Sonnet CXLI
line: Who in despite of view is pleased to dote;

title: Sonnet CXLI
line: Nor are mine ears with thy tongue's tune delighted,

title: Sonnet CXLI
line: Nor tender feeling, to base touches prone,

title: Sonnet CXLI
line: Nor taste, nor smell, desire to be invited

title: Sonnet CXLI
line: To any sensual feast with thee alone:

title: Sonnet CXLI
line: But my five wits nor my five senses can

title: Sonnet CXLI
line: Dissuade one foolish heart from serving thee,

title: Sonnet CXLI
line: Who leaves unsway'd the likeness of a man,

title: Sonnet CXLI
line: Thy proud hearts slave and vassal wretch to be:

title: Sonnet CXLI
line: Only my plague thus far I count my gain,

title: Sonnet CXLI
line: That she that makes me sin awards me pain.

title: Sonnet CXLII
line: Love is my sin and thy dear virtue hate,

title: Sonnet CXLII
line: Hate of my sin, grounded on sinful loving:

title: Sonnet CXLII
line: O, but with mine compare thou thine own state,

title: Sonnet CXLII
line: And thou shalt find it merits not reproving;

title: Sonnet CXLII
line: Or, if it do, not from those lips of thine,

title: Sonnet CXLII
line: That have profaned their scarlet ornaments

title: Sonnet CXLII
line: And seal'd false bonds of love as oft as mine,

title: Sonnet CXLII
line: Robb'd others' beds' revenues of their rents.

title: Sonnet CXLII
line: Be it lawful I love thee, as thou lovest those

title: Sonnet CXLII
line: Whom thine eyes woo as mine importune thee:

title: Sonnet CXLII
line: Root pity in thy heart, that when it grows

title: Sonnet CXLII
line: Thy pity may deserve to pitied be.

title: Sonnet CXLII
line: If thou dost seek to have what thou dost hide,

title: Sonnet CXLII
line: By self-example mayst thou be denied!

title: Sonnet CXLIII
line: Lo! as a careful housewife runs to catch

title: Sonnet CXLIII
line: One of her feather'd creatures broke away,

title: Sonnet CXLIII
line: Sets down her babe and makes an swift dispatch

title: Sonnet CXLIII
line: In pursuit of the thing she would have stay,

title: Sonnet CXLIII
line: Whilst her neglected child holds her in chase,

title: Sonnet CXLIII
line: Cries to catch her whose busy care is bent

title: Sonnet CXLIII
line: To follow that which flies before her face,

title: Sonnet CXLIII
line: Not prizing her poor infant's discontent;

title: Sonnet CXLIII
line: So runn'st thou after that which flies from thee,

title: Sonnet CXLIII
line: Whilst I thy babe chase thee afar behind;

title: Sonnet CXLIII
line: But if thou catch thy hope, turn back to me,

title: Sonnet CXLIII
line: And play the mother's part, kiss me, be kind:

title: Sonnet CXLIII
line: So will I pray that thou mayst have thy 'Will,'

title: Sonnet CXLIII
line: If thou turn back, and my loud crying still.

title: Sonnet CXLIV
line: Two loves I have of comfort and despair,

title: Sonnet CXLIV
line: Which like two spirits do suggest me still:

title: Sonnet CXLIV
line: The better angel is a man right fair,

title: Sonnet CXLIV
line: The worser spirit a woman colour'd ill.

title: Sonnet CXLIV
line: To win me soon to hell, my female evil

title: Sonnet CXLIV
line: Tempteth my better angel from my side,

title: Sonnet CXLIV
line: And would corrupt my saint to be a devil,

title: Sonnet CXLIV
line: Wooing his purity with her foul pride.

title: Sonnet CXLIV
line: And whether that my angel be turn'd fiend

title: Sonnet CXLIV
line: Suspect I may, but not directly tell;

title: Sonnet CXLIV
line: But being both from me, both to each friend,

title: Sonnet CXLIV
line: I guess one angel in another's hell:

title: Sonnet CXLIV
line: Yet this shall I ne'er know, but live in doubt,

title: Sonnet CXLIV
line: Till my bad angel fire my good one out.

title: Sonnet CXLV
line: Those lips that Love's own hand did make

title: Sonnet CXLV
line: Breathed forth the sound that said 'I hate'

title: Sonnet CXLV
line: To me that languish'd for her sake;

title: Sonnet CXLV
line: But when she saw my woeful state,

title: Sonnet CXLV
line: Straight in her heart did mercy come,

title: Sonnet CXLV
line: Chiding that tongue that ever sweet

title: Sonnet CXLV
line: Was used in giving gentle doom,

title: Sonnet CXLV
line: And taught it thus anew to greet:

title: Sonnet CXLV
line: 'I hate' she alter'd with an end,

title: Sonnet CXLV
line: That follow'd it as gentle day

title: Sonnet CXLV
line: Doth follow night, who like a fiend

title: Sonnet CXLV
line: From heaven to hell is flown away;

title: Sonnet CXLV
line: 'I hate' from hate away she threw,

title: Sonnet CXLV
line: And saved my life, saying 'not you.'

title: Sonnet CXLVI
line: Poor soul, the centre of my sinful earth,

title: Sonnet CXLVI
line: [         ] these rebel powers that thee array;

title: Sonnet CXLVI
line: Why dost thou pine within and suffer dearth,

title: Sonnet CXLVI
line: Painting thy outward walls so costly gay?

title: Sonnet CXLVI
line: Why so large cost, having so short a lease,

title: Sonnet CXLVI
line: Dost thou upon thy fading mansion spend?

title: Sonnet CXLVI
line: Shall worms, inheritors of this excess,

title: Sonnet CXLVI
line: Eat up thy charge? is this thy body's end?

title: Sonnet CXLVI
line: Then soul, live thou upon thy servant's loss,

title: Sonnet CXLVI
line: And let that pine to aggravate thy store;

title: Sonnet CXLVI
line: Buy terms divine in selling hours of dross;

title: Sonnet CXLVI
line: Within be fed, without be rich no more:

title: Sonnet CXLVI
line: So shalt thou feed on Death, that feeds on men,

title: Sonnet CXLVI
line: And Death once dead, there's no more dying then.

title: Sonnet CXLVII
line: My love is as a fever, longing still

title: Sonnet CXLVII
line: For that which longer nurseth the disease,

title: Sonnet CXLVII
line: Feeding on that which doth preserve the ill,

title: Sonnet CXLVII
line: The uncertain sickly appetite to please.

title: Sonnet CXLVII
line: My reason, the physician to my love,

title: Sonnet CXLVII
line: Angry that his prescriptions are not kept,

title: Sonnet CXLVII
line: Hath left me, and I desperate now approve

title: Sonnet CXLVII
line: Desire is death, which physic did except.

title: Sonnet CXLVII
line: Past cure I am, now reason is past care,

title: Sonnet CXLVII
line: And frantic-mad with evermore unrest;

title: Sonnet CXLVII
line: My thoughts and my discourse as madmen's are,

title: Sonnet CXLVII
line: At random from the truth vainly express'd;

title: Sonnet CXLVII
line: For I have sworn thee fair and thought thee bright,

title: Sonnet CXLVII
line: Who art as black as hell, as dark as night.

title: Sonnet CXLVIII
line: O me, what eyes hath Love put in my head,

title: Sonnet CXLVIII
line: Which have no correspondence with true sight!

title: Sonnet CXLVIII
line: Or, if they have, where is my judgment fled,

title: Sonnet CXLVIII
line: That censures falsely what they see aright?

title: Sonnet CXLVIII
line: If that be fair whereon my false eyes dote,

title: Sonnet CXLVIII
line: What means the world to say it is not so?

title: Sonnet CXLVIII
line: If it be not, then love doth well denote

title: Sonnet CXLVIII
line: Love's eye is not so true as all men's 'No.'

title: Sonnet CXLVIII
line: How can it? O, how can Love's eye be true,

title: Sonnet CXLVIII
line: That is so vex'd with watching and with tears?

title: Sonnet CXLVIII
line: No marvel then, though I mistake my view;

title: Sonnet CXLVIII
line: The sun itself sees not till heaven clears.

title: Sonnet CXLVIII
line: O cunning Love! with tears thou keep'st me blind,

title: Sonnet CXLVIII
line: Lest eyes well-seeing thy foul faults should find.

title: Sonnet CXLIX
line: Canst thou, O cruel! say I love thee not,

title: Sonnet CXLIX
line: When I against myself with thee partake?

title: Sonnet CXLIX
line: Do I not think on thee, when I forgot

title: Sonnet CXLIX
line: Am of myself, all tyrant, for thy sake?

title: Sonnet CXLIX
line: Who hateth thee that I do call my friend?

title: Sonnet CXLIX
line: On whom frown'st thou that I do fawn upon?

title: Sonnet CXLIX
line: Nay, if thou lour'st on me, do I not spend

title: Sonnet CXLIX
line: Revenge upon myself with present moan?

title: Sonnet CXLIX
line: What merit do I in myself respect,

title: Sonnet CXLIX
line: That is so proud thy service to despise,

title: Sonnet CXLIX
line: When all my best doth worship thy defect,

title: Sonnet CXLIX
line: Commanded by the motion of thine eyes?

title: Sonnet CXLIX
line: But, love, hate on, for now I know thy mind;

title: Sonnet CXLIX
line: Those that can see thou lovest, and I am blind.

title: Sonnet CL
line: O, from what power hast thou this powerful might

title: Sonnet CL
line: With insufficiency my heart to sway?

title: Sonnet CL
line: To make me give the lie to my true sight,

title: Sonnet CL
line: And swear that brightness doth not grace the day?

title: Sonnet CL
line: Whence hast thou this becoming of things ill,

title: Sonnet CL
line: That in the very refuse of thy deeds

title: Sonnet CL
line: There is such strength and warrantize of skill

title: Sonnet CL
line: That, in my mind, thy worst all best exceeds?

title: Sonnet CL
line: Who taught thee how to make me love thee more

title: Sonnet CL
line: The more I hear and see just cause of hate?

title: Sonnet CL
line: O, though I love what others do abhor,

title: Sonnet CL
line: With others thou shouldst not abhor my state:

title: Sonnet CL
line: If thy unworthiness raised love in me,

title: Sonnet CL
line: More worthy I to be beloved of thee.

title: Sonnet CLI
line: Love is too young to know what conscience is;

title: Sonnet CLI
line: Yet who knows not conscience is born of love?

title: Sonnet CLI
line: Then, gentle cheater, urge not my amiss,

title: Sonnet CLI
line: Lest guilty of my faults thy sweet self prove:

title: Sonnet CLI
line: For, thou betraying me, I do betray

title: Sonnet CLI
line: My nobler part to my gross body's treason;

title: Sonnet CLI
line: My soul doth tell my body that he may

title: Sonnet CLI
line: Triumph in love; flesh stays no father reason;

title: Sonnet CLI
line: But, rising at thy name, doth point out thee

title: Sonnet CLI
line: As his triumphant prize. Proud of this pride,

title: Sonnet CLI
line: He is contented thy poor drudge to be,

title: Sonnet CLI
line: To stand in thy affairs, fall by thy side.

title: Sonnet CLI
line: No want of conscience hold it that I call

title: Sonnet CLI
line: Her 'love' for whose dear love I rise and fall.

title: Sonnet CLII
line: In loving thee thou know'st I am forsworn,

title: Sonnet CLII
line: But thou art twice forsworn, to me love swearing,

title: Sonnet CLII
line: In act thy bed-vow broke and new faith torn,

title: Sonnet CLII
line: In vowing new hate after new love bearing.

title: Sonnet CLII
line: But why of two oaths' breach do I accuse thee,

title: Sonnet CLII
line: When I break twenty? I am perjured most;

title: Sonnet CLII
line: For all my vows are oaths but to misuse thee

title: Sonnet CLII
line: And all my honest faith in thee is lost,

title: Sonnet CLII
line: For I have sworn deep oaths of thy deep kindness,

title: Sonnet CLII
line: Oaths of thy love, thy truth, thy constancy,

title: Sonnet CLII
line: And, to enlighten thee, gave eyes to blindness,

title: Sonnet CLII
line: Or made them swear against the thing they see;

title: Sonnet CLII
line: For I have sworn thee fair; more perjured I,

title: Sonnet CLII
line: To swear against the truth so foul a lie!

title: Sonnet CLIII
line: Cupid laid by his brand, and fell asleep:

title: Sonnet CLIII
line: A maid of Dian's this advantage found,

title: Sonnet CLIII
line: And his love-kindling fire did quickly steep

title: Sonnet CLIII
line: In a cold valley-fountain of that ground;

title: Sonnet CLIII
line: Which borrow'd from this holy fire of Love

title: Sonnet CLIII
line: A dateless lively heat, still to endure,

title: Sonnet CLIII
line: And grew a seething bath, which yet men prove

title: Sonnet CLIII
line: Against strange maladies a sovereign cure.

title: Sonnet CLIII
line: But at my mistress' eye Love's brand new-fired,

title: Sonnet CLIII
line: The boy for trial needs would touch my breast;

title: Sonnet CLIII
line: I, sick withal, the help of bath desired,

title: Sonnet CLIII
line: And thither hied, a sad distemper'd guest,

title: Sonnet CLIII
line: But found no cure: the bath for my help lies

title: Sonnet CLIII
line: Where Cupid got new fire--my mistress' eyes.

title: Sonnet CLIV
line: The little Love-god lying once asleep

title: Sonnet CLIV
line: Laid by his side his heart-inflaming brand,

title: Sonnet CLIV
line: Whilst many nymphs that vow'd chaste life to keep

title: Sonnet CLIV
line: Came tripping by; but in her maiden hand

title: Sonnet CLIV
line: The fairest votary took up that fire

title: Sonnet CLIV
line: Which many legions of true hearts had warm'd;

title: Sonnet CLIV
line: And so the general of hot desire

title: Sonnet CLIV
line: Was sleeping by a virgin hand disarm'd.

title: Sonnet CLIV
line: This brand she quenched in a cool well by,

title: Sonnet CLIV
line: Which from Love's fire took heat perpetual,

title: Sonnet CLIV
line: Growing a bath and healthful remedy

title: Sonnet CLIV
line: For men diseased; but I, my mistress' thrall,

title: Sonnet CLIV
line: Came there for cure, and this by that I prove,

title: Sonnet CLIV
line: Love's fire heats water, water cools not love.
